explanations: The descriptive French clause "qui ont merité icy d'estre bien-heureuses" (who have deserved here/on Earth to be blessed) is condensed into the single adjective "blessed" and the noun "Souls." This simplification reduces textual length and omits the explicit mention of meriting this state "icy" (here/on Earth).

The French "un endroit si facheux" (such a troublesome/unpleasant place) refers to a specific negative location. This is simplified to the more abstract phrase "that trouble," reducing the vividness and spatial concreteness of the original.

The French construction "on croit avoir assez pourveu ... de les avoir transportées" (one believes to have sufficiently provided... by having transported them) uses a complex infinitive structure. The English simplifies this to a passive main clause ("'tis thought sufficient provision is made") followed by a more straightforward prepositional phrase with a gerund ("by mutually transporting them"), improving structural clarity.

The personal and more intense French expression "Ce Voyage me réjoüit quelquefois beaucoup" (This voyage sometimes greatly delights me) is simplified to the impersonal and less emphatic "'tis a pleasure." This change reduces the emotive detail by omitting the personal pronoun and adverbs of frequency and intensity.

The French text employs several complex conditional verb forms (e.g., "il faudroit concevoir", "auroient esté faits", "seroit"). The translation simplifies these to more direct indicative tenses ("are made", "that's") or simpler modal constructions ("we must conceive"). The final clause is also rephrased from an abstract conditional ("qu'il y auroit une exception...en faveur de...") to a more concrete statement ("the Earth only was exempted from it"), reducing overall grammatical intricacy.

The French "Je viens de voir le moment que la Lune seroit deserte" (I have just seen/experienced the moment when the Moon would be deserted) uses a personal construction and the conditional "seroit". The translation "it is not long since the Moon was made a Desert" simplifies this by using an impersonal construction and the simple past tense "was made", reducing modality and personal perspective.

The French phrase "comment ils estoient tous faits" (how they were all made), using the imperfect tense, suggests a state or process in a past hypothetical context. The English translation "how they are all made" simplifies this by shifting to the present tense, making the description more immediate but losing the past temporal framing.

The French phrase "je ne laisse pas de trouver qu'il seroit bien étrange" (I do not fail to find / I nevertheless find that it would be very strange) is a somewhat elaborate idiomatic construction. This is simplified in English to the more direct "I think it would be very strange." Additionally, the French imperfect subjunctive forms ("fust", "fussent") are rendered with the simpler "should be" construction.

The French "que la simple veuë ne sçauroit appercevoir" (that simple sight would not know how to/could not perceive) uses a modal conditional verb construction. The English translation "which are not discernable to our plain sight" simplifies this to a more direct adjectival phrase, stating a fact of non-discernibility rather than conveying nuanced incapacity.

The French structure uses imperatives followed by the presentative "voilà aussi-tost..." (there are immediately...). The English translation shifts this to "...and you shall presently see...", making the outcome a direct, predicted observation for "you" (the reader). This makes the cause-and-effect relationship more explicit and personal, simplifying the rhetorical structure from a general statement of appearance to a specific predicted experience.

chunks.sourceHtml: P050: Beaucoup de Corps qui paroissent solides, ne sont que des amas de ces Animaux imperceptibles, qui y trouvent pour leurs mouvemens autant de liberté qu'il leur en faut. Une feüille d'Arbre est un petit Monde habité par des Vermisseaux invisibles, à qui elle paroist d'une étenduë immense, qui y connoissent des Montagnes & des Abismes, & qui d'un costé de la feüille à l'autre n'ont pas plus de communication avec les autres Vermisseaux qui y vivent, que nous avec nos Antipodes. A plus forte raison, ce me semble, une grosse Planete sera-t-elle un Monde habité. On a trouvé jusque dans des especes de pierres tres-dures de petits Vers sans nombre, qui y étoient logez de toutes parts dans des vuides insensibles, & qui ne se nourrissoient que de la substance de ces pierres qu'ils rongeoient. Figurez-vous combien il y avoit de ces petits Vers, & pendant combien d'années ils subsistoient de la grosseur d'un grain de sable; & sur cet exemple, quand la Lune ne seroit qu'un amas de rochers, je la ferois plûtost ronger par ses Habitans que de n'y en pas mettre. Enfin tout est vivant, tout est animé : mettez toutes ces especes d'Animaux nouvellement découvertes, & mesme toutes celles que l'on conçoit aisément qui sont encore à découvrir, avec celles que l'on a toûjours veuës, vous trouverez assurément que la Terre est bien peuplée, & que la Nature y a si liberalement répandu les Animaux, qu'elle ne s'est pas mise en peine que l'on en vist seulement la moitié. Croirez-vous qu'aprés qu'elle a poussé icy sa fecondité jusqu'à l'excés, elle a esté pour toutes les autres Planetes d'une sterilité à n'y rien produire de vivant?
chunks.manualHtml: P046: Many bodies that seem solid, are only a heap of those indiscernable Animals, which find as much liberty for motion there, as they need. The Leaf of a Tree is a little World, inhabited by invisible Worms, to whom it seems a place of immense extent, there they find Mountains and Abysses, and the Worms that inhabit on one side of the Leaf, have no more communication with those on the other side, than we have with the Antipodes. With much more reason, in my opinion, a great Planet may be a World inhabited. There has been found even in some kind of exceeding hard Stones innumerable little Worms lodg'd in all parts in insensible vacuities, and were only nourish'd with the substance of the stone; imagine with your self how many little Worms there might be, and how many years they subsisted upon a bit no bigger than a grain of Sand; and according to this example, were the Moon only an heap of Rocks, rather than there should be no Inhabitants, I would make them gnaw upon those Rocks. In fine, all things have Life, all are animated; take you all those species of Animals newly discover'd, and those that we may easily judge are yet to be discover'd, together with those that we daily see, and you will certainly find that the Earth is well peopl'd, and that Nature has been so liberal in Animals, that she never took care that half of them should be seen: do you believe then, that having been so fruitful in her Productions here even to excess, she has been so barren in the other Planets, as to produce nothing living?

explanations: The French original features a long, continuous series of relative clauses ('à qui...', 'qui y connoissent...', 'qui d'un costé...'). The English translation simplifies this complex sentence structure by: (1) converting the relative clause 'qui y connoissent des Montagnes & des Abismes' into a new, coordinated clause 'there they find Mountains and Abysses,' thus breaking the chain of subordination; and (2) replacing the noun phrase with a relative clause 'les autres Vermisseaux qui y vivent' with the more concise pronominal phrase 'those on the other side.' These changes enhance readability by reducing syntactic complexity and density.

The French original employs a rhetorical interrogative ('sera-t-elle...?') to deliver a strong assertion, a common stylistic feature of Fontenelle. The English translation simplifies this by using a declarative sentence with the modal verb 'may be' ('a great Planet may be...'). This modification makes the statement more direct and less stylistically marked, reducing the rhetorical complexity of the original.

The French text includes the descriptive clause 'qu'ils rongeoient' (which they were gnawing), specifying how the worms consumed the stone. The English translation omits this clause, thereby simplifying the sentence by reducing its informational detail and length.

The French 'que de n'y en pas mettre' is a concise but somewhat complex idiomatic negative infinitive construction ('than to not put any there'). The English translation recasts this part by fronting the condition and using a more explicit phrasing: 'rather than there should be no Inhabitants.' This restructuring and more direct statement of the negative condition simplifies the original's denser phrasing, enhancing clarity.

The French clause 'que l'on en vist seulement la moitié' utilizes the imperfect subjunctive 'vist' (that one saw/might see), a grammatical mood and tense that can be complex. The English translation simplifies this by employing a more common and analytically straightforward modal construction 'that half of them should be seen.' This change simplifies the grammatical structure for the English reader.

chunks.sourceHtml: P051: Ma raison est assez bien convaincuë, dit la Marquise, mais mon imagination est accablée de la multitude infinie des Habitans de toutes ces Planetes, & embarrassée de la diversité qu'il faut établir entre eux; car je voy bien que la Nature, selon qu'elle est ennemie des repetitions, les aura tous faits différens, mais comment se representer cela? Ce n'est pas à l'imagination à prétendre le représenter, répondis-je, elle n'est pas propre à aller plus loin que les yeux. On peut seulement apercevoir d'une certaine veuë universelle, la diversité que la Nature doit avoir mise entre tous ces Mondes. Tous les visages sont en general sur un mesme modele; mais ceux de deux grandes Nations, comme des Européens, si vous voulez, & des Africains, paroissent estre faits sur deux modeles particuliers, & il faudroit encore trouver le modele des visages de chaque Famille. Quel secret doit avoir eu la Nature pour varier en tant de manieres une chose aussi simple qu'un visage? Nous ne sommes dans l'Univers que comme une petite Famille, dont tous les visages se ressemblent; dans une autre Planete, c'est une autre Famille dont les visages ont un autre air..
chunks.manualHtml: P047: I am convinc'd, said the Marchioness, in my reason; but my imagination is overwhelm'd with that infinite multitude of Inhabitants in all the Planets, and confounded with the diversity that must needs be among them; for I well see that Nature, as she is an enemy of repetitions, has made them all different, but how shall we represent it? The Imagination, said I, cannot pretend to represent it, she can go no farther than the Eyes lead her: one certain general view may give a prospect of that diversity that Nature has wrought in all those Worlds. All Faces in general are wrought according to one and the same model, but those of two great Nations, of the Europeans, for example, and Africans seem to be fram'd to two particular models, and we may yet find a particular model in the Faces of every Family. What secret should Nature have in framing such variety in one only thing so simple as a Face? We are in the Universe but as one little Family, where all the Faces resemble; another Planet is another Family, where the Faces have another Air.

explanations: The French "qu'il faut établir" implies a need to actively ascertain or define the diversity. The English "that must needs be" shifts to asserting an inherent, existing state of diversity, simplifying the nuance of the cognitive or epistemological task suggested by the original.

The French future perfect "aura faits" conveys a strong supposition or deduction about a past action. The English present perfect "has made them" simplifies this by presenting the action as a completed fact, reducing the explicit conjectural nuance of the original.

The French phrase "n'est pas propre à aller" (is not suited/apt to go) is simplified to the more direct and common modal construction "can go no farther." This change makes the expression of capability more straightforward.

The translation restructures the sentence, shifting agency from the human perceiver ("On peut seulement apercevoir" - One can only perceive) to an abstract "view." Additionally, the French modal "doit avoir mise" (must have put/placed), indicating strong inference about a past action, is simplified to "has wrought," which states a completed action without the explicit deductive nuance. This simplifies the sentence's perspective and the expression of modality.

The original French "si vous voulez" (if you wish/like) is a direct, conversational address, maintaining the dialogic nature of the text. The English "for example" is a more impersonal and standard phrase, simplifying the interactive tone and reducing the stylistic richness of the original conversational style.

The French impersonal construction "il faudroit ... trouver" (it would be necessary to find), using the conditional to express necessity or a hypothetical task, is simplified. The English changes to a personal "we" and uses "may ... find," shifting from necessity to possibility. This simplifies both the grammatical structure (impersonal to personal) and the modal nuance.

The French phrase "pour varier en tant de manieres" (in order to vary in so many ways) is condensed to the more concise "in framing such variety." This simplification reduces the explicitness about the diverse methods of variation, focusing more on the result.

The French "dans une autre Planete, c'est une autre Famille" uses an introductory prepositional phrase followed by "c'est..." (it is...). The English translation "another Planet is another Family" simplifies this structure by making "another Planet" the direct subject of the verb "is," creating a more direct and streamlined predication.

chunks.sourceHtml: P052: Apparemment les differences augmentent à mesure que l'on s'éloigne, & qui verroit un Habitant de la Lune, & un Habitant de la Terre, remarqueroit bien qu'ils seroient de deux Mondes plus voisions qu'un Habitant de la Terre & un Habitant de Saturne. Icy, par exemple, on a l'usage de la voix, ailleurs on ne parle que par signes, plus loin on ne parle point du tout. Icy le raisonnemét se forme entierement par l'experience; ailleurs l'experience y ajoûte fort peu de chose, plus loin les Vieillards n'en sçavent pas plus que les Enfants. Icy on se tourmente de l'avenir plus que du passé; plus loin on ne se tourmente ny de l'un ny de l'autre, & ceux-là ne sont peut-estre pas les plus malheureux. On dit qu'il pourroit bien nous manquer un sixiéme Sens naturel, qui nous aprendroit beaucoup de choses que nous ignorons. Ce sixiéme Sens est apparemment dans quelque autre Monde, où il manque quelqu'un des cinq que nous possedons. Peut-estre mesme y a-t-il effectivement un grand nombre de Sens naturels; mais dans le partage que nous avons fait avec les Habitans des autres Planetes, il ne nous en est écheu que cinq, dont nous nous contentons faute d'en connoistre d'autres. Nos Sciences ont de certaines bornes que l'Esprit humain n'a jamais pû passer; il y a un point où elles nous manquent tout à coup, le reste est pour d'autres Mondes, où quelque chose de ce que nous sçavons est inconnu. Cette Planete-cy joüit des douceurs de l'Amour, mais elle est toûjours desolée en plusieurs de ses parties par les fureurs de la Guerre. Dans une autre Planete on joüit d'une Paix éternelle, mais au milieu de cette Paix on ne connoist point l'Amour, & on s'ennuye. Enfin ce que la Nature pratique en petit entre les hommes pour la distribution du bonheur où des talens, elle l'aura sans doute pratiqué en grand entre les Mondes, & elle se sera bien souvenuë de mettre en usage ce secret merveilleux qu'elle a de diversifier toutes choses, & de les égaler en mesme temps que les compensations.
chunks.manualHtml: P048: 'Tis most certain that the differences increase in proportion to the distances, and whoever should see an Inhabitant of the Moon and an Inhabitant of the Earth, would easily observe that they were of two Worlds nearer Neighbours than an Inhabitant of the Earth and an Inhabitant of Saturn; here for example we use the Voice, in another place they speak but by Signs, and farther off they speak not at all: Here Reason is wholly form'd by Experience, there Experience contributes little, and farther off old men know no more than children: Here we perplex our selves more for the future than what is past, farther off they concern themselves neither for the one nor the other, and those perhaps are not the most unhappy. It has been thought that we want a sixth natural Sense, by which we might know many things more than we do; that sixth Sense is doubtless in some other World, where possibly they want some one of our five: Nay, perhaps there are really a great number of natural Senses; but in the Distribution made with the Inhabitants of other Planets, only five fell to our share, wherewith we content our selves, because we know no other. Our Knowledge has certain bounds and limits which the Mind of Man cannot exceed, there is a certain point where it wholly fails us, and the rest is for some other World, where likewise something that we know is unknown: This Planet enjoys the Sweets of Love, but in many parts is laid desolate by the fury of War: In another Planet they enjoy perpetual Peace, but know nothing of Love, and are uneasie. In fine, what Nature has done in little among men in her distribution of Happiness or other Talents, she has doubtless done in great among the several Worlds, and did not at all forget that wonderful secret of hers in working a variety in all things, and yet at the same time making them equal by Compensations.

explanations: The French "Apparemment" (apparently, seemingly) at the start of the clause is translated to the stronger "'Tis most certain." This simplifies the original's nuanced expression of likelihood into a more direct and forceful assertion.

The French "remarqueroit bien" (would indeed notice/observe well) contains "bien" for emphasis on the quality or certainty of observation. The translation "would easily observe" simplifies this by shifting the emphasis to the ease of observation, using a more common adverb.

The impersonal French construction "on a l'usage de la voix" (one has the use of the voice) is simplified to the more direct and personal "we use the Voice," making the statement less abstract and more relatable.

The French phrase "l'experience y ajoûte fort peu de chose" (experience adds very little to it) is a somewhat periphrastic construction. The English "Experience contributes little" simplifies this into a more concise and direct statement, reducing textual density.

The French "n'en sçavent pas plus" (don't know more about it/of it) includes the pronoun "en," adding a slight referential complexity. The English "know no more" simplifies this by omitting the "en," resulting in a more direct, though slightly less nuanced, statement.

The French "Apparemment" (apparently, seemingly) in this clause is translated as "doubtless." This simplifies the original's nuanced expression of likelihood or appearance into a more assertive statement of certainty.

The French verb "échoir" (to fall to one's lot) in "il ne nous en est écheu que cinq" (only five have accrued to us) is relatively formal. The English "only five fell to our share" uses more common vocabulary and a familiar idiom, simplifying the diction.

The French "faute d'en connoistre d'autres." (for want of knowing others) uses a somewhat formal prepositional phrase to express cause. The English "because we know no other." simplifies this structure into a more direct and common clausal explanation.

The translation omits the French adverb "toûjours" (always) from the phrase "elle est toûjours desolée" (it is always desolated). This omission simplifies the text by removing the temporal detail of continuous action, reducing informational density.

The French "on s'ennuye." (one is bored/experiences ennui) describes a specific, deep-seated weariness. The English "and are uneasie." simplifies this to a more general and less specific state of discomfort, reducing the cultural and emotional nuance of "ennui."

The French verb "pratique" (practices, carries out), suggesting a methodical or habitual action, is translated as "has done." This simplifies the vocabulary to a more general term, reducing the nuance of systematic action.

The French future perfect "elle se sera bien souvenuë" (she will have well remembered) followed by the infinitive phrases "de mettre en usage" (to put to use) and "qu'elle a de diversifier" (that she has to diversify) forms a complex structure. The English translation simplifies this using a direct past tense "[she] did not at all forget" (with "and" connecting it to the previous subject) and a gerund phrase "in working a variety," creating a more direct and structurally less complex statement.

chunks.sourceHtml: P053: Etes-vous contente, Madame, ajoûtay-je en quittant le ton serieux? Vous ay-je dubité assez de chimeres? Vrayment, répondit-elle, il me semble que j'ay presentement moins de peine à attraper les differences de tous ces Mondes. Mon imagination travaille sur le plan que vous m'avez donné. Je me represente comme je puis des Caracteres & des Coûtumes extraordinaire pour les Habitans des Planetes, & je leur compose mesme des figures tout-à-fait bizarres. Je ne vous les pourrois pas décrire, mais je voy pourtant quelque chose. Pour ces figures-là, repliquay-je, je vous conseille d'en laisser le soin aux Songes que vous aurez cette nuit. Nous verrons demain s'ils vous auront bien servie, & s'ils vous auront appris comment sont faits les Habitants de quelque Planete.
chunks.manualHtml: P049: Well, Madam, said I, laying aside my serious tone, are you now satisfied? Have I given you Chimera's enough? Truly, says she, I have now less trouble methinks to find out the difference of all those Worlds, my Imagination is now busie about the Plain you have given me. I represent to my self, as well as I can, extraordinary Characters and Customs for the Inhabitants of the Planets, and I frame strange and extravagant figures for them. I cannot well describe them to you, but I see something. As for those figures, says I, I advise you to remit them to the Dreams you will have this night, we shall see to morrow whether they assisted you well in it, and inform'd you of the Shape of the Inhabitants of any Planet.

explanations: The French verb "dubiter" (to doubt, or in an older sense, to present things for doubting/consideration) potentially carries more complex intellectual nuance. The translation uses the simpler, more common verb "given," which primarily denotes provision, thereby reducing the potential speculative or philosophical richness of the original phrase.

The French phrase "d'en laisser le soin" (literally, 'to leave the care of them') uses the pronominal adverb "en" and a phrasal verb construction. The translation "to remit them" simplifies this structure by employing a single verb with a direct object, resulting in a more concise and grammatically direct expression, even if "remit" itself is not necessarily simpler vocabulary.

The original French uses the future perfect tense ("auront ... servie," "auront appris") to describe actions that will have been completed in the future relative to another future event ("Nous verrons demain"). The translation simplifies this tense structure by using the simple past tense ("assisted," "inform'd"). This change makes the temporal relationship more direct and arguably easier for the reader to process, though it sacrifices the specific nuance of the future perfect.

The French phrase "comment sont faits les Habitants" inquires broadly about the constitution, nature, or makeup of the inhabitants ('how they are made'). The translation significantly narrows this to "the Shape of the Inhabitants." This is a semantic simplification, reducing a complex and potentially philosophical question about the beings' entire nature to a more concrete and limited inquiry about their physical form, thereby diminishing the conceptual richness of the original.

chunks.manualHtml: P050: THE Fourth Evening.

chunks.sourceHtml: P055: Les songes ne furent point heureux: ils representerent toûjours quelque chose qui ressembloit à ce que l'on voit icy. J'eus lieu de reprocher à la Marquise ce que nous reprochent à la veüe de nos Tableaux, de certains Peuples qui ne font jamaïs que des peintures bizarres & grotesques. Bon, nous disent-ils, cela est tout fait comme des hommes, il n'y a pas là d'imagination. Il falut donc se resoudre à ignorer les figures des Habitans de toutes ces Planetes, & se contenter d'en deviner ce que nous pourrions, en continuant le Voyage des Mondes que nous avions commencé. Nous en estions à Venus. On est bien seur, dis-je à la Marquise, que Venus tourne sur elle-mesme, mais on ne sçait pas bien en quel temps, ny par consequent combien ses jours durent. Pour ses années, elles ne sont que de huit mois, puis qu'elle tourne en ce temps-là autour du Soleil. Come elle est quarante fois plus petite que la Terre, la Terre de dedans Venus paroist une Planete quarante fois plus grande, que Venus ne nous paroist d'icy; & comme la Lune est aussi quarante fois plus petite que la Terre, elle paroist dedans Venus à peu prés de la mesme grandeur dont Venus nous paroist d'icy.
chunks.manualHtml: P051: Our Dreams were not successful, they only represented something resembling what we had seen, and I had opportunity of reproching the Marchioness, as those people who never draw any thing but what is extravagant and grotesque reproch us at the sight of our Pictures. Very well, say they, those are men to the life, there's nothing there of fancy, We were fain then to be still ignorant of the Figures of the Inhabitants of the Planets, and content our selves with guessing at them as well as we could, continuing the Voyage we had began about the World: we were in Venus. 'Tis certain, said I to the Marchioness, that Venus turns about her self, but 'tis not well known in what time, nor consequently how long her days are; as for her years, they are but eight months, for in so much time she turns about the Sun. She is forty time less than the Earth, therefore the Earth in Venus seems a Planet forty times bigger than Venus appears to us from hence: and as the Moon is likewise forty times less than the Earth, she seems in Venus very near about the same bigness that Venus appears to us from hence.

explanations: The complex French object clause 'ce que nous reprochent ... de certains Peuples,' which specifies the content of a reproach by an embedded agent, is restructured into a simpler adverbial clause of comparison 'as those people... reproch us.' This simplifies the grammatical nesting and makes the intended analogy more explicit for easier comprehension.

The concise French phrase 'd'en deviner ce que nous pourrions,' using the pronoun 'en' and the general 'ce que nous pourrions' (what we could), is translated into the more explicit 'guessing at them' and the common English idiom 'as well as we could.' This simplification enhances readability by making the pronominal reference clear and using more familiar phrasing.

The French idiomatic expression 'Nous en estions à Venus' (literally, 'We were at it at Venus,' signifying having reached that point/stage) is translated to the simpler, more direct 'we were in Venus.' This simplification prioritizes a literal statement of current topic/location over the nuanced idiomatic meaning of progression.

The French 'On est bien seur' (One is very sure) includes the intensifier 'bien' (very). The English translation ''Tis certain' omits this intensifier, reducing the phrase's density by removing a qualifying word and making the assertion more direct.

The French uses 'Come' (As/Since) to implicitly establish a causal link for the following clause. The translation omits this initial conjunction and instead inserts 'therefore' to make the logical connection explicit, simplifying the argumentative structure. Additionally, the specific 'de dedans Venus' (from within Venus) is simplified to the more general 'in Venus,' reducing descriptive specificity.

The specific French prepositional phrase 'dedans Venus' (from within/inside Venus) is simplified to the more general 'in Venus.' The French 'grandeur' (size, magnitude) is rendered as 'bigness,' a more common and less formal vocabulary choice in this context. The comparative construction 'de la mesme grandeur dont...' is also translated to the simpler 'the same bigness that...,' reducing phrasal complexity.

chunks.sourceHtml: P056: Vous m'affligez, dit la Marquise. Je voy bien que la Terre n'est pas pour Vénus l'Etoile du Berger, & la Mere des Amours, comme Vénus l'est pour la Terre; car la Terre de dedans Vénus paroist trop grande, mais la Lune qui y paroist de la mesme grandeur dont Vénus nous paroist d'icy, est justement taillée comme il faut pour y estre Mere des Amours, & Etoile du Berger. Ces noms ne peuvent convenir qu'à une petite Planete qui soit jolie, claire, brillante, & qui ait un air galant. C'est asseurément une destinée agréable pour nostre Lune que de presider aux Amours des Habitans de Venus; ces Gens là doivent bien entendre la galanterie. Oh! sans doute, répondis-je, le menu Peuple de Venus n'est composé que de Celadons & de Silvandres, & leurs Conversations le plus communes valent les plus belles de Clesie. Le climat est tres-favorable aux Amours. Venus est plus proche que nous du Soleil, & elle en reçoit une lumiere plus vive & plus de chaleur.
chunks.manualHtml: P052: You vex me, said the Marchioness, I see well that the Earth is not for Venus, the Star of Shepherds and Mother of Love, as Venus is to the Earth; for the Earth in Venus appears too big, but the Moon that appears there of the same bigness that Venus doth to us from hence, is of a just proportion to be the Mother of Love and Star of Shepherds; those names are only fit for a little Planet that is brisk, clear, sparkling, and of a gallant Air. 'Tis certainly a destiny very pleasing to our Moon, to influence the Loves of the Inhabitants of Venus; those people must needs understand Gallantry well. Oh! no question on't, said I, the little people of Venus are made up of none but Celadons, and Sylvanders, and their most ordinary Conversation is beyond the most polite of Clelia, the Climate is extremely favourable for Love; Venus is nearer the Sun than we, and she receives from him a Light more lively and hot.

explanations: The French "grandeur" (magnitude, size) is translated to "bigness." "Bigness" is a more common, less formal, and simpler vocabulary choice compared to "grandeur" or more formal alternatives like "magnitude."

The French "presider aux Amours" (to preside over Loves) implies a formal, authoritative role. The translation "to influence the Loves" uses a more common verb ("influence") and suggests a softer, less direct, and arguably more easily understood type of agency, thus simplifying the conceptualization of the Moon's role.

The French "menu Peuple" (common people, ordinary folk) is translated to "the little people." This simplifies the socio-lexical register by using a more colloquial and arguably more accessible term, though it may also shift the nuance slightly.

The French phrase "une lumiere plus vive & plus de chaleur" (a more lively light and more heat) is rendered as "a Light more lively and hot." This simplifies the structure by changing the noun phrase "plus de chaleur" (more heat) into the common adjective "hot," making the expression more concise and direct.

The French adjective "brillante" (shining, brilliant) is translated to "sparkling." While "brilliant" is a cognate, "sparkling" is arguably a more common, vivid, and less formal adjective in this descriptive context, simplifying the vocabulary towards more readily accessible imagery.

The French "valent les plus belles de Clesie" (are worth/are equivalent to the most beautiful [conversations] of Clélie) is translated as "is beyond the most polite of Clelia,". This simplifies the comparison from a nuanced equivalence to a clear statement of superiority, making the relationship more straightforward and emphatic for the reader.

chunks.sourceHtml: P057: Je vois presentement, interrompit la Marquise, comment sont faits les Habitans de Venus. Ils ressemblent aux Mores Grenadins; un petit Peuple noir, brûlé du Soleil, plein d'esprit & de feu, toûjours amoureux, faisant des Vers, aimant la Musique, inventant tous les jours des Festes, des Danses, & des Tournois. Permettez-moy de vous dire, Madame, repliquay-je, que vous ne connoissez guere bien les Habitans de Venus. Nos Mores Grenadins n'auroient esté auprés d'eux que des Lappons & des Groënlandois pour la froideur & pour la stupidité.
chunks.manualHtml: P053: I now see, said the Marchioness, interrupting me, how the Inhabitants of Venus are made, they are like the Moors of Granada, a little black people, Sun-burnt, full of spirit and fire, always amorous, given to Poetry and Musick, and every day Feasting, Dancing and Tilting. Let me tell you, Madam, said I, you know but little of the Inhabitants of Venus; our Moors of Granada for the coldness and stupidity of their Temper would be to them but as people of Lapland or Groenland.

Let me tell you, Madam, said I, you know but little of the Inhabitants of Venus; our Moors of Granada for the coldness and stupidity of their Temper would be to them but as people of Lapland or Groenland.
explanations: The French uses three distinct present participial phrases describing active pursuits ('faisant des Vers' - making verses; 'aimant la Musique' - loving music; 'inventant...' - inventing...). The translation simplifies this structure and meaning: 1. It condenses 'faisant des Vers, aimant la Musique' into a single, more idiomatic adjectival phrase 'given to Poetry and Musick,' which describes a general disposition rather than two separate active engagements, streamlining the list. 2. It replaces 'inventant tous les jours des Festes, des Danses, & des Tournois' (inventing festivals, dances, and tournaments every day) with the gerunds 'every day Feasting, Dancing and Tilting.' This shifts the meaning from the act of *creating* or *devising* these events daily (implied by 'inventant') to simply *engaging* in them, using more common verbs for these activities and simplifying the described intellectual effort.

The French sentence uses a conditional perfect tense ('n'auroient esté' - would have been) and the prepositional phrase 'auprés d'eux' (literally 'beside them', meaning 'in comparison to them'). The English translation simplifies these aspects. Firstly, the verb tense is simplified from the conditional perfect 'n'auroient esté' to the conditional present 'would be', reducing the complexity of the hypothetical state being described. Secondly, the nuanced comparative phrase 'auprés d'eux' is rendered as the more direct and concise 'to them'. While the English sentence also reorders the concluding French phrase ('pour la froideur & pour la stupidité') to an earlier position as 'for the coldness and stupidity of their Temper' and adds minor explicitations ('of their Temper', 'people of'), the primary simplifications contributing to easier readability are the change in verb tense and the more straightforward rendering of the comparison.

chunks.sourceHtml: P058: Mais que sera-ce des Habitants de Mercure? Ils sont encore plus proches du Soleil; il faut qu'ils soient fous à force de vivacité. Je croy qu'ils n'ont point de memoire, non plus que la plupart des Négres; qu'ils ne font jamais de reflexion sur rien, qu'ils n'agissent qu'à l'aventure, & par des mouvemens subits, & qu'enfin c'est dans Mercure que sont les Petites Maisons de l'Univers. Ils voyent le Soleil beaucoup plus grand que nous ne le voyons, parce qu'ils en sont beaucoup plus proches. Il leur envoye une lumiere si forte, que s'ils estoient icy, ils ne prendroient nos plus beaux jours que pour de tres-foibles Crepuscules, & peut-estre n'y pourroient-ils pas distinguer les objets, & la chaleur à laquelle ils sont accoûtumez est si excessive, que celle qu'il fait icy au fond de l'Afrique, suffiroit pour les glacier. Leur année n'est que de trois mois. La durée de leur jour ne nous est point encore connuë, parce que Mercure est si petit & si proche du Soleil, dans les rayons duquel il est presque toûjours perdu, qu'il échappe à toute l'adresse des Astronomes, & qu'on n'a pû encore avoir assez de prise sur luy, pour observer le mouvement qu'il doit avoir sur son centre; mais sa petitesse fait croire qu'il acheve ce tour en peu de temps; que par consequent le jour de Mercure est fort court, & que les Habitans voyent le Soleil comme un grand poêle ardent, peu éloigné de leurs testes, & qui va d'une rapidité prodigieuse. Cela en est mieux pour eux, car apparemment ils soûpirent aprés la nuit. Ils sont éclairez pendant ce temps-là de Venus,& de la Terre, qui leur doivent paroistre assez grandes. Pour les autres Planetes, comme elles sont au-delà de la Terre vers le Firmament, ils les voyent plus petites que nous ne les voyons, & n'en reçoivent que bien peu de lumiere, peut-estre n'en reçoivent-ils point du tout. Les Etoles Fixes sont aussi plus petites pour eux, & même il doit y en avoir beaucoup qui disparoissent entierement; c'est, selon moy, une perte. Je suis bien fàché de voir cette grande voûte ornée de mois d'Etoiles, & de ne voir celles qui me resteroient, que plus petites, & d'une couleur plus effacée..
chunks.manualHtml: P054: But what are the Inhabitants of Mercury? they are yet nearer the Sun, and therefore certainly must needs be fools with too much vivacity. I believe they have no memory no more than the greatest part of Negro's and that they never consider on any thing, nor act but by chance, and suddain motions; and in fine, that Mercury is the Bedlam of the Universe. They see the Sun much bigger than we do, because they are much nearer, and he gives them so strong a light, that were they here, they would esteem our fairest days but as weak twilight, and perhaps would not be able to distinguish Objects by it, and they are us'd to so excessive a Heat, that they would freez in the midst of Africa; their year is but three months, the length of their day is yet unknown to us; for Mercury is so little and so near the Sun, in whose Rays he is almost continually lost, that he escapes all observation of Astronomers, and they cannot yet lay hold on him so much as to observe what motion he makes about his Center: but his smalness makes them believe that he performs that Course in a little time, and that therefore the days in Mercury are short, and that the Inhabitants see the Sun like a great burning Stove or Kettle not far above their heads, and moving with a prodigious rapidity. It is well for them, for 'tis certain they are very desirous of the night, during which time they are inlightened by Venus and the Earth, which ought to appear very big to them. As for the other Planets, they being beyond the Earth toward the Firmament, seem less to them than they do to us, and they receive but little or perhaps no Light at all from thence. The fixed Stars likewise seem less to them, and many are not seen at all, which in my opinion is a loss. I am not well pleas'd to see that great Arch adorn'd with lesser Stars, and not to see the rest but in a less proportion and a duller colour.
chunks.aiHtml: P054: But what are the Inhabitants of Mercury? they are yet nearer the Sun, and therefore certainly must needs be fools with too much vivacity. I believe they have no memory no more than the greatest part of Negro's and that they never consider on any thing, nor act but by chance, and suddain motions; and in fine, that Mercury is the Bedlam of the Universe. They see the Sun much bigger than we do, because they are much nearer, and he gives them so strong a light, that were they here, they would esteem our fairest days but as weak twilight, and perhaps would not be able to distinguish Objects by it, and they are us'd to so excessive a Heat, that they would freez in the midst of Africa; their year is but three months, the length of their day is yet unknown to us; for Mercury is so little and so near the Sun, in whose Rays he is almost continually lost, that he escapes all observation of Astronomers, and they cannot yet lay hold on him so much as to observe what motion he makes about his Center: but his smalness makes them believe that he performs that Course in a little time, and that therefore the days in Mercury are short, and that the Inhabitants see the Sun like a great burning Stove or Kettle not far above their heads, and moving with a prodigious rapidity. It is well for them, for 'tis certain they are very desirous of the night, during which time they are inlightened by Venus and the Earth, which ought to appear very big to them. As for the other Planets, they being beyond the Earth toward the Firmament, seem less to them than they do to us, and they receive but little or perhaps no Light at all from thence. The fixed Stars likewise seem less to them, and many are not seen at all, which in my opinion is a loss. I am not well pleas'd to see that great Arch adorn'd with lesser Stars, and not to see the rest but in a less proportion and a duller colour.
explanations: The French "que sera-ce des..." is a somewhat more elaborate phrasing for "what about..." or "what will be the case for...". The English "what are..." is a more direct, common, and simpler interrogative construction.

The French "toute l'adresse" refers to "all the skill/cleverness." The English "all observation" shifts focus to the direct outcome (inability to observe). "Observation" is a more concrete and common term in this context than the nuanced "adresse," simplifying by stating the result rather than the abstract cause (failure of skill).

The French "fort court" (very short) is an intensified adjective. The English translation uses the simpler adjective "short" (from the phrase "the days in Mercury are short"), omitting the intensifier "fort" (very). This reduces textual density and the specific degree of shortness conveyed.

The French "de tres-foibles Crepuscules" (of very weak twilights) contains the intensifier "tres-" (very) modifying "foibles" (weak). The English "weak twilight" (from the phrase "but as weak twilight") omits this intensifier, directly translating "foibles" but simplifying the description by reducing the emphasis on the degree of weakness.

The French "Cela en est mieux pour eux," (literally, "That is all the better for them,") contains "mieux" (better), implying comparison, and "en" for emphasis. The English "It is well for them," simplifies this by using "well" instead of "better," removing the explicit comparative aspect and the emphasis, resulting in a flatter, less nuanced statement.

The French phrase "& même il doit y en avoir beaucoup qui disparoissent entierement" (and even there must be many that disappear entirely) uses "même" (even) for emphasis and "il doit y en avoir" (there must be) expressing probability. The English "and many are not seen at all" simplifies this by omitting the emphasis ("même"), removing the modal of probability ("il doit y en avoir"), and rephrasing more directly, thus reducing structural complexity and nuance.

The French phrase "celles qui me resteroient," (literally "those which would remain for me," referring to stars) is more elaborate, conditional, and personal. The English "the rest" is a significantly simpler, more concise, and general term, reducing the length and descriptive richness.

chunks.sourceHtml: P059: Je ne suis pas si touchée, dit la Marquise, de cette perte-là que sont les Habitans de Mercure, que de l'incommodité qu'ils reçoivent de l'excés de la chaleur. Je voudrois bien que nous les soulageassions un peu. Donnons à Mercure de longues & d'abondantes pluyes qui le rafraischissent, comme on dit qu'il en tombe icy dans les Pays chauds pendant des quatre mois entiers, justement dans les saisons les plus chaudes.
chunks.manualHtml: P055: I am not, said the Marchioness, so much concern'd at that loss of the Inhabitants of Mercury, as at the inconveniences they suffer by the extremity of Heat. I wish we could procure their ease; therefore pray let us allow in Mercury long and abundant Rain to refresh them, as 'tis said it falls here in hot Countrys for four months together just in the hottest Seasons.
chunks.aiHtml: P055: I am not, said the Marchioness, so much concern'd at that loss of the Inhabitants of Mercury, as at the inconveniences they suffer by the extremity of Heat. I wish we could procure their ease; therefore pray let us allow in Mercury long and abundant Rain to refresh them, as 'tis said it falls here in hot Countrys for four months together just in the hottest Seasons.
explanations: The French uses a somewhat complex and potentially ambiguous relative clause 'que sont les Habitans de Mercure' (literally 'that are the Inhabitants of Mercury') to link the 'loss' with the inhabitants. The English translation simplifies this syntactically by using a more direct and common possessive/attributive construction 'of the Inhabitants of Mercury,' which clarifies the relationship (loss experienced by the inhabitants) and makes the phrase easier to parse.

The translator omits the French phrase 'un peu' (a little), which qualifies the extent of relief the Marquise wishes for the inhabitants of Mercury. This omission reduces a specific detail from the original text, thereby simplifying the Marquise's expressed wish by removing the nuance of degree.

The French original states the rains 'refresh it' ('le rafraischissent'), with the pronoun 'le' (it) referring to the planet Mercury. The English translation changes the object to 'them,' referring to the previously mentioned 'Inhabitants of Mercury.' This alteration makes the direct benefit to the inhabitants more explicit, simplifying the referential link for the reader and making the purpose of the rains immediately clear in relation to the inhabitants' comfort.

chunks.sourceHtml: P060: Cela se peut, repris-je, & mesme nous pouvons rafraîchir encore Mercure d'une autre façon. Il y a des Pays dans la Chine qui doivent estre tres-chauds par leur situation, & où il fait pourtant de grands froids pendant les mois de Juillet & d'Aoust, jusque-là que les Rivieres se gelent. C'est que ces contrées là ont beaucoup de Salpêtre; les exhalaisons en sont fort froides, & la force de la chaleur les fait sortir de la Terre en grande abondance. Mercure sera, si vous voulez, une petite Planete toute de Salpêtre, & le Soleil tirera d'elle-mesme le remede au mal qu'il luy pourroit faire. Ce qu'il y a de seur, c'est que la Nature ne sçauroit faire vivre les Gens qu'où ils peuvent vivre, & que l'habitude jointe à l'ignorance de quelque chose de meilleur, survient, & les y fait vivre agréablement. Ainsi on pourroit même se passer dans Mercure du Salpêtre & des pluyes.
chunks.manualHtml: P056: That may be, said I, and we may likewise refresh Mercury another way. Some parts of China, which by their scituation ought to be very hot, are yet so extreme cold in the months of Iuly and August, that the Rivers are frozen: The cause is, those Countrys are full of Saltpeter, the Exhalations whereof are very cold, and the great Heats exhale them from the Earth in great abundance. Mercury, if you please, shall be a little Planet all of Saltpeter, and the Sun shall produce from it self a remedy for the evil that it caused. Most certain it is, that Nature cannot make people live any where but where they can live, and that Custome joyn'd with Ignorance of what is better, makes them live there well enough. So in Mercury they may live well enough without Saltpeter or Rain.

explanations: The French "encore" (still/again/further), implying an addition to previously discussed or assumed methods of refreshing Mercury, is omitted in the English translation. This omission simplifies the phrase by removing a layer of nuance about the sequential or additive nature of the suggestion, making the statement more direct.

The French impersonal construction "où il fait ... de grands froids" (where it makes/is ... great colds) is restructured into a simpler adjectival predicate where the subject of 'are' is 'Some parts of China' from the main clause: "(Some parts of China...) are yet so extreme cold." This simplifies the sentence structure from an impersonal verb acting on a noun phrase to a copula with an adjective. Additionally, "de grands froids" (great colds) is translated as "extreme cold," using more common and standard English vocabulary for intense cold.

The French introductory phrase "C'est que" (It is that / The reason is that), which can be less direct, is translated as the more explicit "The cause is," simplifying the logical connection for the reader. Furthermore, "ont beaucoup de Salpêtre" (have a lot of saltpeter) is rendered as "are full of Saltpeter," using a common and arguably more vivid English idiom ("full of") than a direct translation like "have a lot of," streamlining the expression.

The conditional mood in "au mal qu'il luy pourroit faire" (for the harm that it could/might do to it) is simplified to the past indicative "that it caused." This change significantly simplifies the grammatical structure by replacing a hypothetical or potential event with a factual past event, thereby reducing the original's speculative nuance. Additionally, the verb 'tirera d'elle-mesme' (will draw/extract from itself) is translated as 'produce from it self,' which may be a slightly more common or less metaphorical verb choice in this context of a remedy being generated.

The verb "survient" (intervenes, arises, comes along), which denotes a distinct action or process, is effectively omitted, or its meaning is absorbed into the verb "makes them live." This simplifies the sentence structure by reducing the number of explicit actions. Moreover, the adverb "agréablement" (pleasantly, agreeably) is translated as "well enough," which is a simplification of vocabulary and a reduction in the richness of meaning, changing a clearly positive state to a more neutral, minimally sufficient one.

The French modal "on pourroit" (one could - conditional) is simplified to "they may" (present possibility). The emphatic adverb "même" (even), which adds a layer of emphasis or surprise, is omitted, reducing textual density and nuance. The core phrase "se passer de" (to do without/dispense with) is expanded to "live well enough without." This expansion makes the implication of managing to live under these conditions more explicit by directly linking it to the preceding discussion on habitability, thus simplifying the inferential step for the reader.

chunks.sourceHtml: P061: Aprés Mercure vous sçavez qu'on trouve le Soleil. Il n'y a pas moyen d'y mettre d'Habitans. Le Pourquoy non nous manque-là. Nous jugeons par la Terre qui est habitée, que les autres Corps de la mesme espece qu'elle, doivent l'estre aussi; mais le Soleil n'est point un Corps de la mesme espece que la Terre, ny que les autres Planetes. Il est la source de toute cette lumiere que les Planetes ne font que se renvoyer les unes aux autres, aprés l'avoir reçeüe de luy. Elles ne peuvent faire, pour ainsi dire, des échanges entre elles, mais elles ne la peuvent produire. Luy seul tire de soy-mesme cette pretieuse substance; il la pousse avec force de tous costez; de là elle revient à la rencontre de tout ce qui est solide, & d'une Planete à l'autre il s'épand de longues & vastes traisnées de lumieres qui se croisent & se traversent, & s'entrelassent en mille façons diferentes, & forment d'admirables tissus de la plus riche matiere qui soit au monde. Aussi le Soleil est-il placé dans le centre, qui est le lieu le plus commode d'où il la puisse distribuer également, & animer tout par sa chaleur. Le Soleil est donc un Corps particulier, mais quelle sorte de Corps? On est bien embarrassé à le dire. On avoit toûjours crû que c'estoit un feu tres-pur, mais on s'en desabusa au commencement de ce Siecle, qu'on apperceut des taches sur sa surface. Comme on avoit découvert peu de temps auparavant de nouvelles Planetes dont je vous parleray; que tout le Monde Philosophe n'avoit l'esprit remply d'autre chose, & qu'enfin les nouvelles Planetes s'estoient mises à la mode, on jugea aussi-tost que ces taches en estoient; qu'elles avoyent un mouvement autour du Soleil, & qu'elles nous en cachoient necessairement quelque partie, en tournant leur moitié obscure vers nous. Déja les Sçavans faisoient leur Cour de ces pretendües Planetes à tous les Princes de l'Europe. Les uns leur donnoient le nom d'un Prince, les autres d'un autre, & peut-estre il y auroit eu querelle entre-eux à qui seroit demeuré le maistre des taches pour les nommer comme il eust voulu...
chunks.manualHtml: P057: Next after Mercury you know is the Sun, there is no way of making him habitable, the cause is clear. We judge by the Earth that is inhabited, that other bodies of the same species may be so likewise, but the Sun is not a body of the same species with the Earth, nor with the other Planets; he is the Fountain of that Light, which the other Planets only reflect from one to another, after having received it from him. They may exchange it, as we may say, among themselves, but they cannot produce it: he only extracts from himself that precious substance, and emits it with vigour on all sides: where ever it meets with any thing that is solid, it reflects, and from one Planet to another long and vast trains of Light cross and traverse one another in a thousand ways, and form an admirable Tissue of the richest material in the World. The Sun likewise is seated in the Center, as a place the most convenient, from whence he may equally distribute his Heat and animate all things with it. The Sun then is a particular, body, but what sort of body, is hard to say. It was ever believ'd to be a most refined fire, but that opinion vanish'd in the beginning of this Age, when the Spots upon his surface were dicover'd. When the new Planets, whereof I shall tell you more, were discover'd not long before, and all the Philosophick World busied their Brains about nothing else, it was presently judg'd that those Spots were the new Planets, that they had a motion about the Sun, and that necessarily they hid some part of him from us, in turning their obscure half toward us. Presently the Virtuoso's began their Flattery with these pretended Planets to all the Princes of Europe, some gave them the name of one Prince, some of another, and perhaps there was a quarrel among them what Prince should be Godfather to the chief of those Spots.

explanations: The French "Le Pourquoy non nous manque-là," literally "The 'why not' (the reason for the negative assertion) is lacking for us there," presents a nuanced, possibly understated or rhetorically complex phrasing. If interpreted (as the subsequent text implies) that the reason is *not* lacking, the English "the cause is clear" directly states this assumed outcome, simplifying the original's rhetorical indirectness and potential subtlety.

The French "de là elle revient à la rencontre de tout ce qui est solide" uses more elaborate phrasing, describing the light's movement as "from there it returns to the encounter of" solid objects. The English "where ever it meets with any thing that is solid, it reflects" simplifies this to a more direct statement of circumstance and consequence, reducing the figurative richness and descriptive detail of the light's specific action of 'returning to meet'.

The French uses three distinct verbs "se croisent" (cross each other), "se traversent" (traverse each other), and "s'entrelassent" (interlace/entwine each other) to describe the complex interaction of light trails. The English translation "cross and traverse one another" omits a direct equivalent for "s'entrelassent," simplifying the description by reducing lexical density and the specific imagery of interlacing.

The French phrase "On est bien embarrassé à le dire" conveys a strong sense of being "quite puzzled" or "very awkward/embarrassed" to state the Sun's nature. The English "is hard to say" simplifies this by using a more common, less intense, and less emotionally nuanced expression, reducing the original's stylistic richness.

The French "on s'en desabusa" (one was disabused of it / one's illusion was dispelled) emphasizes the active process of people realizing their previous error. The English "that opinion vanish'd" uses a more abstract phrasing that personifies the opinion and describes its disappearance somewhat passively, simplifying the human agency involved in the shift of understanding.

The original French sentence presents three coordinated causal clauses starting with "Comme..." and "que..." explaining the judgment about sunspots. The English translation omits the third causal clause: "& qu'enfin les nouvelles Planetes s'estoient mises à la mode" (and that finally the new Planets had come into fashion). This omission simplifies the complex sentence structure by reducing the number of contributing reasons and removes a specific socio-cultural observation about scientific trends, thereby reducing the text's density.

The French "n'avoit l'esprit remply d'autre chose" (literally "had its mind/spirit filled with nothing else") is translated into the more colloquial and idiomatic English phrase "busied their Brains about nothing else." This simplifies the original's more formal and slightly abstract vocabulary by using a common, vivid expression, making the language more direct.

The French "faisoient leur Cour de ces pretendües Planetes à..." (literally "were paying court with these pretended planets to...") implies seeking favor, possibly through flattery but can be broader. The English "began their Flattery with..." makes the act of flattery explicit and central. This simplifies the original expression by removing the slight ambiguity or broader connotation of "faire la cour" and opting for a more direct and unambiguously interpretive term.

The French phrase "à qui seroit demeuré le maistre des taches pour les nommer comme il eust voulu..." (as to who would have remained master of the spots to name them as he would have wished...) describes the power dynamic and prerogative over naming. The English translation "what Prince should be Godfather to the chief of those Spots." simplifies this by replacing the more abstract notion of "mastery for naming" with the more concrete, culturally familiar, and slightly jocular role of "Godfather," and by adding the detail "chief of those Spots," making the scenario more vivid but altering the original's focus.

chunks.sourceHtml: P062: Je ne trouve point cela bon, interrompit la Marquise. Vous me disiez l'autre jour qu'on avoit donné aux differentes parties de la Lune des noms de Sçavans & d'Astronomes, & j'en estois fort contente. Puis que les Princes prennent pour eux la Terre, il est juste que les Sçavans se reservent le Ciel, & y dominent, mais ils n'en devroient point permettre l'entrée à d'autres. Souffrez, répondis-je, qu'ils puissent, du moins en cas de besoin, engager aux Princes quelque Astre, ou quelque partie de la Lune. Quant aux taches du Soleil, ils n'en purent faire aucun usage. Il se trouva que ce n'estoient point des Planetes, mais des nuages, des fumées, des écumes, qui s'élèvent sur le Soleil. Elles sont tantost en grande quantité, tantost en petit nombre; tantost elles disparoissent toutes, quelquefois elles se mettent plusieurs ensemble, quelquefois elles se separent, quelquefois elles sont plus claires, quelquefois plus noires. Il y a des temps où l'on en voit beaucoup, il y en a d'autres, & mesme assez longs, où il n'en paroist aucune. Il semble que le Soleil soit une matiere liquide, quelques-uns disent de l'Or fondu, qui boüillonne incessamment, & produit des impuretez, qui par la force de son mouvement sont rejettées sur sa surface. Elles s'y consument, & puis il s'en produit d'autres. Imaginez-vous quels Corps étrangers ce sont là. Il y en a tel qui est peut-estre aussi grand que la Terre. Jugez par là quelle est la quantité de cet Or fondu, ou l'étenduë de cette grande Mer de lumiere & de feu qu'on appelle le Soleil. D'autres disent que le Soleil paroît avec des Lunettes tout plein de Montagnes qui vomissent des flâmes, & que c'est comme un million de Monts Etna mis ensemble, mais on dit aussi que ces Montagnes sont une pure vision, causée par quelque chose qui arrive dans les Lunettes. Aquoy se fiera-t-on, s'il faut se défier des Lunettes mesme, ausquelles nous devons la connoissance de tant de nouveaux objects. Enfin, quoy que ce puisse estre que le Soleil, il ne paroist nullement propre à estre habité. C'est pourtant dommage, l'habitation seroit belle. On seroit au centre de tout, on verroit toutes les Planetes tourner regulierement autour de soy, au lieu que nous voyons dans leur cours une infinité de bizareries, qui n'y paroissent que parce que nous ne sommes pas en le lieu propre pour en bien juger, c'est à dire, au centre de leur mouvement. Cela n'est-il pas pitoyable? Il n'y a qu'un lieu dans le Monde, d'où l'étude des Astres puisse estre extremément facile, & justement dans ce lieu-là, il n'y a personne. Vous n'y songez pas, dit la Marquise. Qui seroit dans le Soleil, verroit rien, ny Planetes, ny Etoiles Fixes. Le Soleil n'efface-t-il pas tout? Ce seroient ses Habitans qui seroient bien fondez à se croire seuls dans toute la Nature.
chunks.manualHtml: P058: I do not approve of that, said the Marchioness, you told me the other day, that the different parts of the Moon were call'd by the names of Virtuoso's and Astronomers, and I was well satisfy'd. For since Princes have the Earth to themselves, it is but just the Virtuoso's should reserve the Heavens to themselves, and govern there without admitting any Rivals. You may allow them, said I, in case of necessity, to ingage a Star or part of the Moon to a Prince; as for the Spots of the Sun, they can make no use of them. It has been found that they are not Planets, but Clouds, or Fumes, or Froth that rises upon the Face of the Sun: sometimes they are many, sometimes few, sometimes they wholly disappear, sometimes many of them crowd together, sometimes they separate, sometimes they appear more clear and sometimes more obscure, sometimes many of them are seen, and at other times for a long while together none appear at all. The Sun seems to be some liquid matter, some think melted Gold that boyls incessantly, and produces those impurities, which by the force of his motion are thrown out upon his surface, where they consume, and he afterward produces more. Imagine with your self what strange bodies those are, some of them are, it may be, as big as the Earth, judge from thence how great is the quantity of that melted Gold, and how large that Sea of Light and Fire which we call the Sun. Others say that the Sun appears in the Telescope full of Mountains that vomit Flame, and it seems a million of Aetna's put together, but they say likewise that those mountains are a meer appearance, caus'd by some accident in the Telescope. But what then shall we trust to, if we must distrust the Telescope, to which we owe the knowledge of so many new Objects? In fine, whatever the Sun be, it appears not at all fit to be inhabited, which certainly is a great loss; for it would be a delicate Habitation: We should be in the Center of all, and should see the Planets move regularly about him, whereas now we see an infinite extravagance in their motions, because we are not in a place proper to judge of them, that is in the Center, is not that a pity? There is but one place in the World where the study of the Stars would be extreme easie, and in that very place there's not a man. You never consider, said the Marchioness, that whoever should be in the Sun would see nothing at all, neither Planets nor fixed Stars. Does not the Sun hide all? So it would be with his Inhabitants, who would indeed have good reason to believe themselves the only Creatures in Nature.

explanations: The translation shifts from the French "passé simple" (past historic "purent," indicating a completed past action or inability) to a present tense ("can make"). This simplifies the temporal nuance, making the statement about the usability of sunspots more general and immediate rather than tied to a specific past attempt or realization.

The translation changes the French imperfect tense "n'estoient point" (were not), which describes a past state at the time of discovery, to the English present tense "are not". This shift simplifies the temporal perspective, presenting the nature of sunspots as a current, established fact rather than framing it within the narrative's timeline of discovery.
The French phrases "en grande quantité" (in great quantity) and "en petit nombre" (in small number) are simplified to the more common and concise English words "many" and "few".

The French construction "Il y a des temps où l'on en voit beaucoup" (There are times when one sees many of them) is simplified to "sometimes many of them are seen." This changes the impersonal "l'on en voit" (one sees) to a passive voice and uses the more common adverb "sometimes" instead of the clausal "Il y a des temps où" (There are times when).

The French impersonal passive-like construction "puis il s'en produit d'autres" (then others of them are produced / then more are produced) is simplified to an active voice construction "and he afterward produces more," with "he" (the Sun) as the explicit agent. This makes the sentence more direct and its agent clearer.

The French construction "Il y en a tel qui est peut-estre..." (There is such a one of them that is perhaps...) is simplified to the more direct and common English phrasing "some of them are, it may be...". This avoids the slightly more formal and less direct "tel qui" construction.

The somewhat vague French phrase "quelque chose qui arrive dans les Lunettes" (something that happens in the telescopes) is translated as "some accident in the Telescope." The word "accident" simplifies by providing a more specific lexical choice than the general "something that happens," making the idea more concrete and readily understood.

The French "C'est pourtant dommage" (It is however a pity/shame) is translated as "which certainly is a great loss." This changes the concessive/regretful nuance of "pourtant" (however/yet) to an emphatic "certainly" and intensifies "dommage" (pity/shame) to "a great loss." This makes the statement more direct and less understated, simplifying the emotional expression.

The translation omits the phrase "de leur mouvement" (of their movement) from the original "au centre de leur mouvement." This shortens the phrase and relies on the preceding context to imply what "Center" refers to, thereby reducing the explicitness and density of the original text.

The French "verroit rien" (would see nothing) is rendered as "would see nothing at all." The addition of "at all" is an intensifier not explicitly present in the original "rien" (which in older French could stand alone for 'nothing' in such constructions), making the negation more emphatic and absolute. This can be seen as a form of simplification by ensuring the extent of "nothing" is fully and easily grasped.

The French verb "effacer" (to erase, wipe out, make indistinct) is translated with the simpler and more common English verb "hide." While "efface" exists in English, "hide" uses more common vocabulary, reducing the lexical formality.

The French idiomatic and somewhat formal phrase "seroient bien fondez à se croire" (literally, "would be well-founded to believe themselves") is translated into the more common and slightly more analytical English phrase "would indeed have good reason to believe themselves." This simplifies the idiomatic structure into a more readily understandable phrasing. The addition of "So" at the beginning also simplifies the logical connection to the preceding sentence.

chunks.sourceHtml: P063: J'avoüe que je m'estois trompé, répondis-je, je ne songeois qu'à la situation où est le Soleil,& non à l'effet de sa lumiere; mais vous qui me redressez si à propos, vous voulez bien que je vous dise que vous vous estes trompée aussi; les Habitans du Soleil ne le verroient seulement pas. Ou ils ne pourroient soûtenir la force de sa lumiere, ou ils ne la pourroient recevoir, faute d'en estre à quelque distance, & tout bien considéré, le Soleil ne seroit qu'un séjour d'Aveugles; encore un coup, il n'est pas fait pour estre habité; mais voulez-vous que nous poursuivions nostre Voyage des Mondes? Nous sommes arrivéz au centre qui est toûjours le lieu le plus bas dans tout ce qui est rond, il faudroit presentement retourner sur nos pas, & remonter. Nous retrouverons Mercure, Venus, la Terre, la Lune, toutes Planetes que nous avons visitées. Ensuite c'est Mars qui se presente. Mars n'a rien de curieux que je sçache, ses jours ne sont pas d'une heure entiere plus longs que les nostres; ses années valent deux de nos années. Il est plus petit que la Terre, il voit le Soleil un peu moins grand & moins vif que nous ne le voyons; enfin Mars ne vaut pas trop la peine qu'on s'y arreste. Mais la jolie chose que Jupiter avec ses quatre Lunes ou Satellites! Ce sont quatre petites Planetes qui tournent autour de luy, comme nostre Lune tourne autour de nous. Mais, interrompit la Marquise, pourquoy y a-t-il des Planetes qui tournent autour d'autres Planetes qui ne valent pas mieux qu'elles? Serieusement il me paroîtroit plus regulier & plus uniforme que toutes les Planetes, grandes & petites, n'eussent que le mesme mouvement autour du Soleil!
chunks.manualHtml: P059: I confess, said I. I was mistaken, I only consider'd the Scituation of the Sun, and not the effect of his Light; but you that correct me so aptly, must give me leave to tell you, that you are as much mistaken as my self, the Inhabitants of the Sun would not see him at all. Either they would not be able to suffer the force of his Light, or they could not receive it being not plac'd at a distance from it; all which being well consider'd, the Sun would be only an abode of Blind people: But to prevent all that, it is not made to be inhabited. Will you then that we prosecute our Voyage about the Worlds? We are come to the Center, which is always the lowest place in any thing that is round, we must now return and ascend again, and shall meet in our way Mercury, Venus, the Earth and the Moon, Planets that we have already visited. The next that offers is Mars, who has nothing curious in him, that I know, his days are not a whole hour longer than ours, but his years are as long as two of ours: he is less than the Earth, and sees the Sun neither so big nor so bright as we. In fine, Mars has nothing in him worth the while to detain us. But the jolly Iupiter with his four Moons or Satellits is worth a Visit. They are four little Planets that turn about him as the Moon turns about as. But, says the Marchioness, interrupting me, why! are there Planets that turn about other Planets no better than themselves? Seriously it would seem to me more regular and uniform that all Planets both great and small should have but one and the same motion about the Sun.

explanations: The concise French causal phrase "faute d'en estre à quelque distance" (for lack of being at some distance) is rendered into a more explicit participial clause "being not plac'd at a distance from it." This unpacks the implicit causality in "faute de," making the reason for not being able to receive light more spelled out for the reader, thereby simplifying the dense French phrasing.

The French idiomatic phrase "encore un coup," which serves as an emphatic conclusion (akin to "in short" or "to reiterate"), is replaced by "But to prevent all that." This translation simplifies the rhetorical transition by providing an explicit, albeit altered, logical connection of purpose or prevention, making the flow of argument more straightforward for the reader than the original's abrupt, summative force.

The impersonal French construction "il faudroit" (it would be necessary/one should) is simplified to the more direct and personal "we must," clarifying agency. Additionally, the idiomatic and slightly more descriptive "retourner sur nos pas" (retrace our steps) is rendered as the more common and straightforward "return," simplifying the vocabulary.

The French "valent" (are worth/equivalent to) is translated as "are as long as." While "valent" is not inherently complex, "are as long as" is a more common and direct English idiom for expressing duration. This simplifies the original's slightly more abstract term in this specific context by using more frequent and specific vocabulary related to time.

The translation omits the French qualifier "un peu" (a little), which modifies "moins grand & moins vif" (less big & less vivid). By changing it to "neither so big nor so bright," the statement becomes more absolute and less nuanced. This omission simplifies the description by removing a degree of qualification, making the assertion more direct.

The French exclamatory sentence structure "Mais la jolie chose que Jupiter..." (But what a pretty thing Jupiter is...!) is transformed into a declarative statement: "But the jolly Iupiter... is worth a Visit." This simplification changes the rhetorical effect from an expression of wonder to a more straightforward factual assertion, making the communication more direct and less stylistically complex.

chunks.sourceHtml: P064: Ah! Madame, répliquay-je! Si vous sçaviez ce que c'est que les Tourbillons de Descartes, ces Tourbillons dont le nom est si terrible, & l'idée si agreable, vous ne parleriez pas comme vous faites. La teste me dust-elle tourner, dit-elle en riant, il est beau de sçavoir ce que c'est que les Tourbillons. Achevez de me rendre folle, je ne me ménage plus, je ne connois plus de retenuë sur la Philosophie; laissons parler le monde, & donnons-nous aux Tourbillons. Je ne vous connoissois pas de pareils emportemens, répris-je; c'est dommage qu'ils n'ayent que les Tourbillons pour objet. Ce qu'on appelle un Tourbillon, c'est un amas de matiere dont les parties sont détachées les unes des autres, & se meuvent toutes en un mesme sens; permis à elles d'avoir pendant ce temps-là quelques petites mouvemens particuliers, pourveu qu'elles suivent toûjours le mouvement general. Ainsi un Tourbillon de vent, c'est une infinité de petites parties d'air, qui tournent en rond toutes ensemble, & enveloppent ce qu'elles rencontrent. Vous sçavez que les Planetes sont portées dans la matiere celeste, qui est d'une subtilité, & d'une agitation prodigieuse. Tout ce grand amas de matiere celeste, qui est depuis le Soleil jusqu'aux Etoiles fixes, tourne en rond, & emportant avec soy les Planetes, les fait tourner toutes en un mesme sens autour du Soleil, qui occupe le centre; mais en des temps plus ou moins longs, selon qu'elles en sont plus ou moins éloignées. Il n'y a pas jusqu'au Soleil qui ne tourne; mais il ne tourne que sur luy-mesme, parce qu'il est justement au milieu de toute cette matiere celeste; & vous remarquerez en passant, que quand la Terre seroit dans la place où il est, elle ne pourroit encore faire moins que de tourner sur elle-mesme.
chunks.manualHtml: P060: Ah! Madam, said I, did you but know what the Vortices of Descartes are, Vortices whose name is so terrible and Idea so agreeable, you would not talk as you do. What, says she laughing, must my Head turn round? 'twill be pleasant to know what these Vortices are; pray make an end of fooling me, I can no longer govern my self, nor muse longer upon Philosophy, let us leave talking of the World, and begin with these Vortices. I never knew you so transported, said I, 'tis pity there is any other Objects than Vortices. A Vortex is a mass of matter whose parts are lose one from the other, and move all in conformity to themselves; but in the mean time you must allow them some little particular motions, provided they still follow the general motion. So a Whirlwind is an infinity of little parts of Air, that turn round altogether and inclose all they meet. You know the Planets are carried in the celestial matter, which is of a prodigious subtilty and agitation. All that great mass of celestial matter from the Sun to the fixed Stars turns round and carrying the Planets with it, makes them turn all uniformly about the Sun, which possesses the Center, but in more or less time, according as their distances are more or less from him. All even to the Sun it self turn, but he turns only about himself, because he is just in the Center of that celestial matter, and you must observe by the way, that were the Earth in the Center it could do no less than turn upon its own Axis.
