explanations: The single, somewhat literary French inverted conditional clause "La teste me dust-elle tourner" (Should my head spin) is broken into a more conversational interjection ("What,") and a direct question ("must my Head turn round?"), simplifying the sentence structure. Additionally, the phrase "il est beau de sçavoir" (it is a fine thing/good to know), which implies worthiness, is simplified to the more common and affectively simpler "'twill be pleasant to know."

The French "Achevez de me rendre folle" (Finish making me mad/crazy) expresses a stronger, more dramatic emotion. The English "pray make an end of fooling me" uses more common vocabulary ("fooling me") and simplifies the intensity of the Marquise's statement.

The French expresses a dual concept: abandoning self-preservation ("je ne me ménage plus") and abandoning formal restraint regarding philosophy ("je ne connois plus de retenuë"). The English simplifies this into more general phrasing: "I can no longer govern my self" is a common expression for losing self-control, and "nor muse longer upon Philosophy" uses a common verb ("muse") that softens and simplifies the idea of casting off "retenuë" (restraint/reserve).

The French idiomatic expression "laissons parler le monde" (let the world/people talk, implying disregard for societal opinion) is simplified to "let us leave talking of the World," which changes the meaning to merely switching conversational topics. Further, the figurative and intense "donnons-nous aux Tourbillons" (let's give ourselves up to/devote ourselves to the Vortices) is simplified to the much plainer and more common instruction "and begin with these Vortices."

The French uses the plural noun "emportemens" (strong outbursts of passion/enthusiasm), suggesting a capacity for such states. The English "so transported" uses an adjective describing her current state, which is a simpler grammatical construction and employs a more common term for being carried away by emotion, reducing the specific force of "emportemens."

The French "c'est dommage qu'ils n'ayent que les Tourbillons pour objet" conveys a subtle, flirtatious regret that the Marquise's passions are *only* directed at Vortices (implying they might be directed elsewhere, e.g., at the speaker). The English translation simplifies this complex emotional and situational nuance into a more straightforward, although semantically different, statement. The English structure is simpler than the French subordinate clause but sacrifices the specific cultural nuance of gallantry.

The French definitional structure "Ce qu'on appelle un Tourbillon, c'est..." (That which one calls a Vortex, it is...) is a common but slightly more periphrastic phrasing. The English "A Vortex is..." simplifies this to a more direct and concise sentence structure.

The French uses an impersonal passive construction "permis à elles" (it being permitted to them) and the somewhat formal temporal phrase "pendant ce temps-là" (during that time). The English translation changes this to the more direct, active, and conversational "you must allow them" and the common phrase "in the mean time." This simplifies the formal, detached tone and grammatical structure by using direct address and more common vocabulary.

The French structure "Ainsi un Tourbillon de vent, c'est..." (Thus a whirlwind, it is...) includes a resumptive pronoun "c'est," which is a common feature of French syntax for emphasis or flow. The English translation "So a Whirlwind is..." omits this, resulting in a more direct and streamlined sentence structure typical of English, thereby simplifying the slightly more complex French phrasing.

The French descriptive phrase "en un mesme sens" (in the same direction/manner) is translated to the single adverb "uniformly." While "uniformly" is not necessarily simpler vocabulary in isolation, its use here condenses a prepositional phrase into a single adverb, streamlining the sentence and making the expression more compact.

The French "vous remarquerez en passant" (you will notice in passing) uses the future indicative, politely predicting an observation. The English translation "you must observe by the way" changes this to a more direct and instructional tone using "must observe," simplifying the nuanced politeness of the original phrasing.

The French phrase "que quand la Terre seroit dans la place où il est" (that if the Earth were in the place where it [the Sun] is) contains a reference ("où il est") that the reader must resolve. The English translation "that were the Earth in the Center" simplifies this by making the location explicit ("in the Center"), thereby enhancing clarity and reducing the interpretative step for the reader.

The French "elle ne pourroit encore faire moins que de tourner sur elle-mesme" includes the word "encore" (still/yet), which is omitted in the English "it could do no less than turn upon its own Axis," slightly reducing textual density. Furthermore, the general phrase "tourner sur elle-mesme" (to turn on itself) is rendered as the more scientifically specific "turn upon its own Axis." In the context of popularizing science, this specification clarifies the abstract notion of self-rotation, simplifying comprehension by providing a more concrete image of the motion.

chunks.sourceHtml: P065: Voila quel est le grand Tourbillon dont le Soleil est comme le Maistre; mais en mesme temps les Planetes se composent de petits Tourbillons particuliers à l'imitation de celuy du Soleil. Chacune d'elles en tournant autour du Soleil, ne laisse pas de tourner autour d'elle-mesme, & fait tourner aussi autour d'elle en mesme sens une certaine quantité de cette matiere celeste, qui est toûjours preste à suivre tous les mouvemens qu'on luy veut donner, s'ils ne la détournent pas de son mouvement general. c'est-là le Tourbillon particulier de la Planete & elle le pousse aussi loin que la force de son mouvement se peut étendre. S'il faut qu'il tombe dans ce petit Tourbillon quelque Planete moindre que celle qui y domine, la voilà emportée par la grande, & forcée indispensablement à tourner autour d'elle, & le tout ensemble, la grande Planete, la petite, & le Tourbillon qui les renferme, n'en tourne pas moins autour du Soleil. C'est ainsi qu'au commencement du Monde nous nous fismes suivre par la Lune, parce qu'elle se trouva dans l'étenduë de nostre Tourbillon, & tout à fait à nostre bienséance. Jupiter dont je commençois à vous parler, fut plus heureux ou plus puissant que nous. Il y avoit dans son voisinage quatre petites Planetes, ils se les assujettit toutes quatre, & nous qui sommes une Planete principale, croyez-vous que nous l'eussions esté, si nous nous fussions trouvés proches de luy? Il est quatre-vingt-dix fois plus gros que nous, il nous auroit engloutis sans peine dans son Tourbillon, & nous ne serions qu'une Lune de sa dépendance, au lieu que nous en avons une qui est dans la nostre, tant il est vray que le seul hazard de la situation décide souvent de toute la fortune qu'on doit avoir.
chunks.manualHtml: P061: You see there what is the great Vortex whereof the Sun is Master, but at the same time the Planets make little particular vortices in imitation of that of the Sun. Each of them in turning about the Sun, turns likewise about it self, and turns together with it a certain quantity of the celestial matter, which is apt to comply with any motion that is given it, if they do not divert it from its general motion. This is the particular Vortex of a Planet, and the Planet pushes it forward as far as the force of its motion can extend. If in that little Vortex a Planet less than that which rules there, do incroach, it is carried on by the greater, and forc'd indispensibly to turn about it: yet nevertheless the great and little Planet, and the Vortex that incloses them, turn about the Sun. So at the beginning of the World, we made the Moon follow us, because she was plac'd within the limits and extent of our Vortex, and wholly at our devotion. Iupiter, of whom I began to tell you, was more happy or more powerful than we, there were four little Planets in his Neighbourhood, and he subdu'd them all; don't you think he would have subdu'd us likewise, who are a principal Planet, had we been his Neighbours? He is ninety times bigger than us, and would doubtless with ease have swallow'd us up in his Vortex, and we should have been no more than a Moon attending on him: whereas we now have one of our own attending on us, So true it is, that the chance only of place and situation often decides the whole fortune of a man.

explanations: The French "se composent de" (are composed of/compose for themselves), part of "les Planetes se composent de petits Tourbillons particuliers", is simplified to the more common and active verb "make" in "the Planets make little particular vortices". This reduces the formality and lexical complexity of the original phrasing.

The idiomatic French construction "ne laisse pas de tourner" (literally "does not leave off turning," meaning "continues to turn" or "still turns"), found in "ne laisse pas de tourner autour d'elle-mesme", is simplified to the more straightforward adverbial phrase "turns likewise" in "turns likewise about it self," making the sentence structure less complex and using more common vocabulary.

The French "n'en tourne pas moins" (lit. "turns no less by it," meaning "still turns" or "nevertheless turns"), part of "n'en tourne pas moins autour du Soleil", uses a nuanced negative construction (litotes) to affirm. The English simplifies this to the direct affirmative verb "turn" in "turn about the Sun," removing the stylistic complexity and making the assertion more straightforward.

The French reflexive causative "nous nous fismes suivre par la Lune," (we caused ourselves to be followed by the Moon) is a grammatically more complex structure. The English translation "we made the Moon follow us," uses a simpler, more direct active causative construction, enhancing readability.

The French "tout à fait à nostre bienséance." (entirely at our convenience/suitability/disposal) is a relatively formal and somewhat abstract term. The English "wholly at our devotion." uses a more common and vivid idiomatic phrase of the period to express subservience, simplifying the original's abstractness with a more concrete image of allegiance.

The French phrase "que nous l'eussions esté," (that we would have been *it*), which uses an anaphoric pronoun "l'" to refer to a previously implied state (being subjected), is made more explicit in the English translation "he would have subdu'd us likewise,". By restating the verb "subdue," the translation reduces referential ambiguity and simplifies comprehension.

The French "une Lune de sa dépendance," (a Moon of his dependence) uses a noun phrase involving an abstract noun ("dépendance") to describe the Moon's status. The English "a Moon attending on him:" replaces this with a more active and descriptive participial phrase, creating a more concrete and easily visualized image of subservience, which simplifies the abstract French.

The French "une qui est dans la nostre," (one which is in ours – implying "our dependence" or "our vortex/control") is concise and relies on inference. The English "one of our own attending on us," is more explicit by specifying possession ("of our own") and using the active phrase "attending on us." This reduces the inferential load for the reader, simplifying by making the meaning more self-contained and descriptive.

The French impersonal pronoun "on" in "qu'on doit avoir." (that one is to have) is rendered as "a man" in "of a man." This shift from a general, impersonal pronoun to a more specific noun (a common practice in older English for a generic person) makes the statement more concrete, which is a form of simplification by reducing abstraction.

chunks.sourceHtml: P066: Et qui nous assure, dit la Marquise, que nous demeurerons toûjours où nous sommes? Je commence à craindre que nous ne fassions la folie de nous approcher d'une Planete aussi entreprenante que Jupiter, ou qu'il ne vienne vers nous pour nous absorber; car il me paroist que dans ce grand mouvement, où vous dites qu'est la matiere Celeste, elle devroit agiter les Planetes irregulierement, tantost les approcher, tantost les éloigner les unes des autres. Nous pourrions aussi-tost y gagner qu'y perdre, répondis-je, peut-estre irions-nous soumettre à nostre domination Mercure & Venus, qui sont de petites Planetes, & qui ne nous pourroient résister. Mais nous n'avons rien à esperer ny à craindre; les Planetes se tiennent où elles sont, & les nouvelles conquestes leur sont défenduës, comme elles l'étoient autrefois aux Rois de la Chine. Vous sçavez bien que quand on met de l'huile avec de l'eau, l'huile surnage. Qu'on mette sur ces deux liqueurs un Corps extremement leger, l'huile le soûtiendra, & il n'ira pas jusqu'à l'eau. Qu'on y mette un autre Corps plus pesant, & qui soit justement d'une certaine pesanteur, il passera au travers de l'huile, qui sera trop foible pour l'arrester, & tombera jusqu'à ce qu'il rencontre l'eau, qui aura la force de le soûtenir. Ainsi dans cette liqueur composée de deux liqueurs qui ne se mêlent point, deux Corps inégalement pesants se mettent naturellement à deux places differentes, & jamais l'un ne montera, ny l'autre ne descendra. Qu'on mette encore d'autres liqueurs qui se tiennent separées, & qu'on y plonge d'autres corps, il arrivera la mesme chose. Representez-vous que la Matiere Celeste qui remplit ce grand Tourbillon, à differentes couches qui s'envelopent les unes les autres, & dont les pesanteurs sont differentes, comme celles de l'huile & de l'eau, & des autres liqueurs. Les Planetes ont aussi differentes pesanteurs; chacune d'elles par consequent s'arreste dans la couche qui a précisément la force necessaire pour la soûtenir, & qui luy fait équilibre, & vous voyez bien qu'il n'est pas possible qu'elle en sorte jamais.
chunks.manualHtml: P062: And what assurance, said the Marchioness, have we of continuing always where we are? I begin so fear we may commit the folly of approaching too near so bold a Planet as Iupiter, or that he may draw toward us to swallow us up; for it seems to me that that great motion of the celestial matter ought to move the Planets irregularly, and draw them sometime nearer, sometime further off from one another. We should as soon gain as lose by that, said I, perhaps we should bring Mercury and Venus, little Planets which could not resist us, into subjection to us. But we need neither hope nor fear, the Planets still keep their old stations and are forbidden to make new Conquests, as heretofore the Kings of China were. You know that in mixing Oil & Water, the Oil swims above, and if you lay upon those two liquors a body extremely light, the Oil will support it that it shall not touch the Water; but if you add another body more heavy of a certain weight, it will pass through the Oil which will be too weak to support it, and will press till it meets the Water, which will be strong enough to bear it. So in that liquor compos'd of two liquors that do not intermix, two bodies of unequal weight do naturally put themselves in two different places, and the one will never ascend, nor the other descend. Again, put together other liquors that shall continue separate and unmixed, and put in other bodies, it will be still the same. Represent to your self that the celestial matter that fills this great Vortex has several lays that infold one another, and whereof the Weights are different, as those of Oil and Water, and other liquors. The Planets have likewise different Weights, and consequently every one of them floats upon the lay, which has exactly a strength necessary to support it, and makes it of such equal poise, that it is not possible it should ever remove from thence.
chunks.aiHtml: P062: And what assurance, said the Marchioness, have we of continuing always where we are? I begin so fear we may commit the folly of approaching too near so bold a Planet as Iupiter, or that he may draw toward us to swallow us up; for it seems to me that that great motion of the celestial matter ought to move the Planets irregularly, and draw them sometime nearer, sometime further off from one another. We should as soon gain as lose by that, said I, perhaps we should bring Mercury and Venus, little Planets which could not resist us, into subjection to us. But we need neither hope nor fear, the Planets still keep their old stations and are forbidden to make new Conquests, as heretofore the Kings of China were. You know that in mixing Oil & Water, the Oil swims above, and if you lay upon those two liquors a body extremely light, the Oil will support it that it shall not touch the Water; but if you add another body more heavy of a certain weight, it will pass through the Oil which will be too weak to support it, and will press till it meets the Water, which will be strong enough to bear it. So in that liquor compos'd of two liquors that do not intermix, two bodies of unequal weight do naturally put themselves in two different places, and the one will never ascend, nor the other descend. Again, put together other liquors that shall continue separate and unmixed, and put in other bodies, it will be still the same. Represent to your self that the celestial matter that fills this great Vortex has several lays that infold one another, and whereof the Weights are different, as those of Oil and Water, and other liquors. The Planets have likewise different Weights, and consequently every one of them floats upon the lay, which has exactly a strength necessary to support it, and makes it of such equal poise, that it is not possible it should ever remove from thence.
explanations: The French relative clause 'où vous dites qu'est la matiere Celeste' (where you say the Celestial matter is), which modifies 'mouvement', is simplified to the prepositional phrase 'of the celestial matter' modifying 'motion'. This removes the explicit meta-commentary ('vous dites'), simplifying the sentence structure and reducing its referential complexity.

The French verb 'agiter' (which can mean to shake, stir, disturb, or set in motion) is translated to 'move.' 'Move' is a more general and common verb, representing a simplification of vocabulary by choosing a less specific and more frequently encountered term.

The French temporal clause 'quand on met de l'huile avec de l'eau' (when one puts oil with water) is simplified to the more concise prepositional phrase with a gerund, 'in mixing Oil & Water.' This change reduces sentence complexity by eliminating an explicit subject ('on') and verb for this part of the action.

The French impersonal subjunctive construction 'Qu'on mette' (Let one put / If one puts) is translated as a conditional clause using 'you' ('and if you lay'). This shift from the impersonal 'on' (one) to the direct address 'you' simplifies the formality of the text and makes the instruction more accessible and engaging for the reader.

Similar to the previous instance, the French impersonal subjunctive 'Qu'on y mette' (Let one put there / If one puts there) is rendered as a more direct conditional clause with 'you' ('but if you add'). This simplification reduces formality and enhances readability by personalizing the scenario for the reader.

The French relative clause '& qui soit justement d'une certaine pesanteur' (and which is/be precisely of a certain weight) is simplified. The adverb 'justement' (precisely, exactly) is omitted, reducing emphasis and textual density. The English 'of a certain weight' directly modifies 'body more heavy,' resulting in a more concise and less overtly clausal structure.

The French hypothetical subjunctive forms 'Qu'on mette' (Let one put / If one puts) and 'qu'on y plonge' (let one plunge there / if one plunges there) are simplified to direct imperative forms 'put together' and 'put in.' This change simplifies the grammatical structure by using a more direct mood, making the instructions easier for the reader to follow.

The French verb 'plonger' (to plunge, immerse, dip) is translated as 'put in.' 'Put in' is a more common and general phrasal verb, simplifying the vocabulary compared to the more specific 'plonge' or its direct English equivalents like 'plunge' or 'immerse.'

The translation omits the introductory conversational French phrase '& vous voyez bien que' (and you see well that / and you understand that). This streamlines the sentence by removing a colloquial appeal to the interlocutor, simplifying its structure and making the concluding statement more direct and less interpersonally marked.

chunks.sourceHtml: P067: Je conçois, dit la Marquise, que ces pesanteurs-là reglent fort bien les rangs. Plust à Dieu qu'il y eust quelque chose de pareil qui les reglast parmi nous, & qui fixast les Gens dans les places qui leur sont naturellement convenables. Me voila fort en repos du costé de Jupiter. Je suis bien-aise qu'il nous laisse dans nostre petit Tourbillon avec nostre Lune unique. Je suis d'humeur à me borner aisément, & je ne luy envie point les quatre qu'il a.
chunks.manualHtml: P063: I understand very well, said the Marchioness, that those weights do well regulate those lays, I wish to God we had some such Regulation among us, that might fix people in the places that are naturally fit for them. You see me now well satisfy'd as to Iupiter, and very well pleas'd that he will let us alone in our little Vortex with our one only Moon; for I am of a humour that easily confine my self, and do not envy him his four.

You see me now well satisfy'd as to Iupiter, and very well pleas'd that he will let us alone in our little Vortex with our one only Moon; for I am of a humour that easily confine my self, and do not envy him his four.
explanations: The French uses an indefinite pronoun "quelque chose de pareil" (something similar) followed by two coordinate relative clauses detailing its functions ("qui les reglast parmi nous" and "qui fixast les Gens"). The English simplifies this by using the more concrete noun "Regulation" and effectively condensing the two functional ideas. The first function (regulating) is absorbed into the noun phrase "some such Regulation among us," and the sentence proceeds with a single relative clause for the second function ("that might fix people"). This reduces syntactic complexity by decreasing the number of explicit verbal clauses modifying the core idea, thereby enhancing directness and readability.

The French "nostre Lune unique" uses the single adjective "unique" (sole, only one of its kind). The English translation "our one only Moon" replaces this with the two-word phrase "one only." This can be seen as a simplification because it uses two very common, arguably more elemental words ("one," "only") to express the concept of singularity, potentially making it more immediately obvious or emphatic for a general reader compared to the single, Latin-derived "unique." This choice prioritizes directness and common vocabulary for popular accessibility.

The French "Me voila fort en repos" (literally "Here I am, very much at rest/peace") uses an idiomatic presentative construction. The English "You see me now well satisfy'd" simplifies this by: 1. Changing the presentative "Me voila" to the more direct conversational address "You see me now," which clarifies the speaker-listener dynamic in a more straightforward manner. 2. Rendering the state "fort en repos" (very much at peace/rest) as "well satisfy'd," which makes the positive emotional state more explicit and its cause (satisfaction about Jupiter) less figurative. This combination enhances directness and conversational clarity.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P068: Vous auriez tort de les luy envier, repris-je, il n'en a point plus qu'il ne luy en faut. Dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil, les Lunes ne reçoivent & ne luy renvoyent, qu'une lumiere assez faible. Il est vray que comme il tourne sur luy-mesme en dix heures, & que ses nuits, qui par consequent n'en durent que cinq, sont fort courtes, quatre Lunes ne paroîtroient pas si necessaires, mais il y a autre chose à considerer. Icy sous les Pôles, on a six mois de jour, & six mois de nuit. C'est que les Pôles sont les deux extremitez de la Terre les plus éloignées des lieux où le Soleil donne à plomb, & sur lesquels il paroit faire sa course. La Lune ne tient, ou paroist tenir la même route à peu prés que le Soleil, & si les Habitans des Pôles voyent le Soleil pendant toute une moitié de sa course d'un an, & pendant toute l'autre moitié ne le voyent point, ils voyent aussi la Lune pendant toute une moitié de sa course d'un mois, c'est à dire, pendant quinze jours, & ils ne la voyent point pendant toute l'autre moitié. Les années de Jupiter en valent douze des nostre, & il doit y avoir dans cette Planete deux extremitez opposées, où l'on ait des jours & des nuits de six ans entiers. Des nuits de six ans sont bien longues, aussi est ce principalement pour elles que je crois que les quatre Lunes sont faites. Celle qui à l'egard de Jupiter est la plus élevée, fait son cercle autour de luy en dix-sept jours, la seconde en sept, la troisiéme en trois jours & demy, la quatrième en quarante-deux heures. Leurs courses estant coupées justement par la moitié pour ces malheureux Pays qui ont six ans de nuit, il ne se peut passer vingt & une heures, qu'on ne voye paroistre au moins la derniere Lune. C'est quelque consolation pendant des tenebres d'une durée si ennuyeuse; mais quelque lieu que l'on habite dans Jupiter, ces quatre Lunes vous y donnent les plus jolis Spectacles du monde. Tantost elles se lèvent toutes quatre ensemble, & puis se separent selon l'inégalité de leur cours; tantost elles sont toutes à leur Midy rangées l'une au dessus de l'autre, tantost on les voit toutes quatre sur l'Horizon à des distances égales; tantost quand deux se levent, deux autres se couchent; sur tout j'aimerois à voir ce jeu perpetuel d'Eclipses qu'elles font, car il ne se passe point de jour qu'elles ne s'éclipsent les unes les autres, ou qu'elles n'éclipsent le Soleil, & asseurément les Eclipses s'estant renduës si familieres en ce Monde-là, elles y sont un sujet de divertissement, & non pas de frayeur, comme en celuy-ci.

P069: Gens de nostre Lune, me fait douter que Jupiter en ait beaucoup sur le Habitans de siennes, & je croy qu'un des avantages ausquels ils puissent le plus raisonnablemént pretendre, c'est de leur faire peur. Par exemple, dans celle qui est la plus proche de luy, ils le voyent trois cents soixante fois plus gros que nostre Lune ne nous paroist, car il la surpasse autant en grosseur. Il est, je croy, beaucoup plus proche d'eux, qu'elle n'est de nous, sa grosseur en augmente encore. Ils fent comme des Colonies de Jupiter; qu'elles eussent receu de luy, s'il estoit possible, leurs Loix & leurs Coûtumes; que par consequent elles luy redissent quelque sorte d'hommage, & ne regardassent la grande Planete qu'avec respect. Ne faudroit-il point aussi, luy dis-je, que les quatre Lunes envoyassent de temps en temps des Députez dans Jupiter, pour luy prester ferment de fidelité? Pour moy, je vous avoüe que le peu de superiorité que nous avons sur les Gens.
chunks.manualHtml: P064: You would do him wrong to envy him, says I, he has no more than he has need of, at the distance he is from the Sun his Moons receive and reflect upon him a very weak Light. 'Tis true that he turning about himself in ten hours, his nights, which continue but five, are very short, and it may seem that he has no necessity of four Moons; but there are other things to be consider'd, here under the Poles we have six months day and six night; for the Poles are the two extremities of the Earth farthest distant from those places through which the Sun seems to make his course. The Moon holds or seems to hold the same course very near that the Sun doth, and as the Inhabitants of the Pole see the Sun for one half of his annual course, and the other half see him not at all; so they likewise see the Moon during one half of her monthly course, that is, for fifteen days, and see her not the other fifteen. The years of Iupiter are twelve of ours, and there ought to be in that Planet two opposite extremities, where the days & nights are of six years continuance: Nights of six years are very long, therefore I believe it was for their sakes that those four Moons were design'd. That which in respect of Iupiter is the highest, makes its course round him in seventeen days, the second in seven, the third in three days and a half, and the fourth in forty hours; their courses being cut just in half for the unhappy people of that Country, who have six years night, they cannot pass one and twenty hours, without seeing at least the last of those Moons 'Tis a Consolation during a Darkness of so tedious a continuance: but in whatever place of Iupiter you inhabit, those four Moons will give you the most pleasant Spectacle in the World. Sometimes they rise all at once, and then separate themselves according to the inequality of their motions, sometimes they are all in their Meridian rang'd the one above the other, sometimes they appear all four above the Horizon at equal distances, sometimes when two of them rise, the other two set, but above all, I should delight to see their Eclipses, for there's not a day passes but they eclipse one another or eclipse the Sun, and certainly Eclipses being so familiar in that World, they are a great subject of Divertisement, and not of Fear as they are here.

explanations: The explicit logical connector "par consequent" (consequently) from the French source is omitted in the English translation. This reduces the lexical density of the sentence, making the causal relationship implicit rather than explicit, thereby streamlining the text for easier readability.

The French introductory phrase "C'est que" (The reason is that/It is that), used to introduce an explanation, is simplified to the more direct conjunction "for." Furthermore, the specific descriptive clause "où le Soleil donne à plomb" (where the Sun is directly overhead/at its zenith), which provides a technical detail about "les lieux" (the places), is omitted in the translation. This simplification reduces scientific detail and information density, making the description more accessible.

The French construction "aussi est-ce...que" (so it is...that / and so it is that...), which links a consequence with emphasis, is translated into a more straightforward structure introduced by "therefore." This simplifies the sentence flow by replacing a slightly more complex and formal emphatic phrasing with a standard logical connector and statement.

The impersonal French construction "il ne se peut passer... qu'on ne voye paroistre" (it cannot pass... that one does not see appear) is simplified. The translation employs a more direct active construction ("they cannot pass") and simplifies the subordinate clause "qu'on ne voye paroistre" to "without seeing." This change makes the sentence more concise and less grammatically complex by avoiding the double negative implication and the explicit verb of appearance ("paroistre").

The French text uses the impersonal pronoun "on" in "on les voit" (one sees them). The English translation changes this to "they appear," making the moons the active subject of the verb. This shift from an impersonal construction to a direct active voice simplifies the sentence by providing a clearer and more straightforward subject-verb relationship, enhancing readability.

The descriptive French phrase "ce jeu perpetuel d'Eclipses qu'elles font" (this perpetual game of Eclipses that they make/do) is significantly condensed to the simpler "their Eclipses." This simplification reduces lexical density, eliminates the metaphorical "jeu perpetuel" (perpetual game), and removes the relative clause "qu'elles font" (that they make), resulting in a more direct and less ornate expression.

The French "s'estant renduës" (a compound past participle from "se rendre," meaning "having become" or "having made themselves") is a relatively complex verbal form indicating a completed action leading to a state. The English translation uses "being so familiar," a simpler present participle construction. This simplifies the verbal aspect, directly stating the resultant state ("being familiar") rather than emphasizing the process of becoming, thus making the grammatical structure more straightforward.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P070: Et vous ne manquerez pas, dit la Marquise, à faire habiter ces quatre Lunes, quoy que ce ne foient que de petites Planetes subalternes, destinées seulement à en éclairer une autre pendant ces nuits? N'en doutez nullement, répondis-je. Ces Planetes n'en sont pas moins dignes d'estre habitées pour avoir le malheur d'estre asservies à tourner autour d'une autre plus importante.

P071: Je voudrais donc, reprit-elle, que les Habitans des quatre Lunes de Jupiter, fussont donc toûjours cette monstrueuse Planete suspédüe sur leurs testes à une distance assez petite. En verité, si les Gaulois craignaient anciennement que le Ciel ne tombast sur eux, les Habitans de cette Lune auroient bien plus de sujet de craindre une chute de Jupiter. C'est peut-estre là aussi la frayeur qu'ils ont, dit- elle, au lieu de celle des Eclipses, dont vous m'avez asseuré qu'ils sont exempts, & qu'il faut bien remplacer par quelque autre sottise? Il le faut de necessité absolüe, répondis-je. L'Inventeur du troisième Systême dont je vous parlois l'autre jour, le celebre Ticho-Brahé, un des plus grands Astronomes qui furent jamais, n'avoit garde de craindre les Eclipses, comme le Vulgaire les craint, il passoit sa vie avec elles. Mais croiriez-vous bien ce qu'il craignoit en leur place? Si en sortant de son logis, la premiere personne qu'il rencontroit estoit une Vieille, si un Lievre traversoit son chemin, Ticho-Brahé croyoit que la journée devoit estre malheureuse, & retournoit promptement se renfermer chez luy, sans oser commencer la moindre chose.
chunks.manualHtml: P065: And you will not fail, said the Marchioness, to people those four Moons likewise, though they are but little subalternate Planets, design'd only to inlighten the nights of another. No doubt on't, said I, those Planets are not at all less worthy to be inhabited for being subjected to turn about another more important. I would then, says she, have it, that the Inhabitants of the four Moons of Iupiter, should be Colonies drawn from him, and that they should receive from him, if possible, their Laws and Customs, and consequently should render him some sort of Homage, and never look upon the great Planet without Respect. And must it not be likewise, said I, that the four Moons should from time to time send their Deputies to Iupiter, to make their Oath of Fidelity? for my part, I assure you that the little Superiority we have over the people of our Moon, makes me doubt whether Iupiter has much over the Inhabitants of his, and I believe the advantage he can most reasonably pretend to, is to frighten them; for example, in that which is nearest to him, he appears to them three hundred and sixty times bigger than our Moon appears to us; for he is so much bigger than she is: he is, I believe, nearer to them than she is to us, which still increases the bigness. They have then that monstrous Planet daily hanging over their heads at a very little distance, and truly if the Gauls of old were afraid the Heavens would fall upon them, the Inhabitants of that Moon have much more cause to fear the fall of Iupiter. That is, possibly, says she, the fear they have instead of that of Eclipses, which you tell me they are free from, but must pay for it by some other folly. That is of absolute necessity, said I; the Inventor of the third System, whom I told you of the other day, the famous Tycho Brahe, the greatest Astronomer that ever was, he fear'd not Eclipses as the vulgar do; for his daily Conversation was with them; but would you believe what he fear'd instead of them? When he went at any time out of his Lodging, if the first person he met were an old Woman, or if a Hare cross'd his way, he believ'd it would be an unlucky day to him, and would presently return and shut himself up, and not dare to take in hand the least matter.

explanations: The French causative construction 'faire habiter' (literally 'to make inhabit' or 'to cause to be inhabited') is simplified to the more direct verb 'to people' (meaning 'to populate'), streamlining the phrasal structure.
The formal French expression 'N'en doutez nullement' (Do not doubt it at all) is translated to the more colloquial and concise 'No doubt on't,' simplifying both vocabulary and register.

The French phrase 'pour avoir le malheur d'estre asservies' (lit. 'for having the misfortune of being subjected/enslaved') includes the explicit mention of 'le malheur' (the misfortune). The English translation 'for being subjected' omits this nuance, simplifying the phrase by reducing its emotional or evaluative content for a more direct statement.

The French verb 'assuré' (assured), implying a strong degree of certainty or formal declaration, is translated to the more common and conversational 'tell me.' This simplifies the vocabulary and slightly lessens the formality and force of the original.

The French 'qu'il faut bien remplacer par' (lit. 'that it is truly necessary to replace with') uses a more analytical construction to convey necessity. The English 'but must pay for it by' employs a common idiom ('pay for it') to express a similar idea of a necessary trade-off or consequence, simplifying the original phrasing into a more vernacular and less literal expression.

The French 'un des plus grands Astronomes qui furent jamais' (one of the greatest Astronomers that ever were) presents a qualified superlative. The English 'the greatest Astronomer that ever was' simplifies this by rendering the superlative as absolute, thereby removing the nuance of comparison within a group and making the statement more direct and less qualified.

The French idiom 'n'avoit garde de craindre' (lit. 'had no care to fear', meaning to be careful not to, or to be far from fearing) is a somewhat elaborate and formal way to express a lack of fear. The English 'he fear'd not' is a more direct and syntactically simpler negation.

The French 'Mais croiriez-vous bien...' includes the particle 'bien,' which adds emphasis (akin to 'really' or 'indeed'). The English translation 'but would you believe...' omits this emphatic particle, resulting in a slightly more straightforward and less intense interrogative phrase.

chunks.sourceHtml: P072: Il ne seroit pas juste, reprit-elle, aprés que cet homme-là n'a pû se delivrer impunément de la crainte des Eclipses, que les Habitans de cette Lune de Jupiter, dont nous parlions, en fussent quittes à meilleur marché. Nous ne leur ferons pas de quartier, ils subiront la Loy commune, & donneront dans quelque autre erreur, mais comme je ne me pique pas de la pouvoir deviner, éclaircissez-moy, je vous prie, une autre difficulté qui m'occupe depuis quelques momens. Si la Terre est si petite à l'égard de Jupiter, Jupiter nous voit-il? Je crains que nous ne luy soyons inconnus.
chunks.manualHtml: P066: It would not be just, said she, since that Man could not deliver himself from the fear of Eclipses, without paying for it by some folly, that the Inhabitants of that Moon of Iupiter, which we speak of, should free themselves with less trouble, we'l give them no Quarter, they shall undergo the Common Law, and fall into some other Errour, but-how, I trouble not my head to guess. Therfore pray explain to me another difficulty has possess'd me within this little while, if the Earth be so little in respect of Iupiter, doth Iupiter see us? I fear we are unknown to him.
chunks.aiHtml: P066: It would not be just, said she, since that Man could not deliver himself from the fear of Eclipses, without paying for it by some folly, that the Inhabitants of that Moon of Iupiter, which we speak of, should free themselves with less trouble, we'l give them no Quarter, they shall undergo the Common Law, and fall into some other Errour, but-how, I trouble not my head to guess. Therfore pray explain to me another difficulty has possess'd me within this little while, if the Earth be so little in respect of Iupiter, doth Iupiter see us? I fear we are unknown to him.
explanations: The French idiomatic expression 'en être quitte à meilleur marché,' meaning to get off more lightly or cheaply, is translated into the more direct and less figurative English phrase 'with less trouble.' This simplifies the language by replacing an idiom with more common and straightforward vocabulary, enhancing readability.

The French verbal expression 'donneront dans' (will fall into, will be taken in by), when used with 'erreur' (error), is translated using the more common and direct English phrasal verb 'fall into.' This choice simplifies the vocabulary by opting for a more standard and readily understood equivalent.

The French phrase 'je ne me pique pas de la pouvoir deviner,' which translates to 'I don't pride myself on being able to guess it' or 'I don't claim to be able to guess it,' uses the nuanced reflexive verb 'se piquer de.' The translation 'I trouble not my head to guess' simplifies this by employing more direct, colloquial language ('trouble not my head') that expresses a simpler idea of not bothering to think about it. This change reduces the original's stylistic nuance. The introductory 'mais comme' (but as/since) is also condensed and rephrased in the target text.

The French verb 'éclaircissez' (literally 'lighten,' meaning clarify, shed light on, or elucidate) is translated to the more common and general English verb 'explain,' simplifying the vocabulary. Furthermore, the translator introduces this clause with 'Therefore,' a conjunction not present in the source, making the logical connection to the preceding thought more explicit. This explicitation and the clearer structural break potentially simplify the sentence flow for the reader.

chunks.sourceHtml: P073: De bonne foy, je croy que cela est, répondis-je. Il faudroit qu'il vist la Terre quatre-vingt-dix fois plus petite que nous ne le voyons. C'est trop peu, il ne la voit point. Voicy seulement ce que nous pouvons croire de meilleur pour nous. Il y aura dans Jupiter des Astronomes, qui aprés avoir bien pris de la peine à composer des Lunettes excellentes, aprés avoir choisy les plus belles Nuits pour observer, auront enfin découvert dans les Cieux une petite Planete qu'ils n'avoyent jamais veüe. D'abord le Journal des Sçavans de ce Pays-là en parle; le Peuple de Jupiter, ou n'en entend point parler, ou n'en fait que rire. Les Philosophes dont cela détruit les opinions, forment le dessein de n'en rien croire, il n'y a que les Gens tres-raisonnables qui en veulent bien douter. On observe encore, on revoit la petite Planete, on s'asseure bien que ce n'est point une vision, on commence même à soupçonner qu'elle a un mouvement autour du Soleil; on trouve au bout de mille observations, que ce mouvement est d'une année; & enfin, grace à toutes les peines que se donnent les Sçavans, on sçait dans Jupiter que nostre Terre est un Monde. Les Curieux vont la voir au bout d'une Lunette, & la veüe à peine peut-elle encore l'attraper.
chunks.manualHtml: P067: Truly, says I, I believe that, he must needs see the Earth ninety times less than we see him, that's too little, he sees it not all: But here's that which we may better believe for our advantage, there may be Astronomers in Iupiter, who having taken pains to make excellent Telescopes, and choosing the fairest nights for Observation, may at last have discover'd in the Heavens a little Planet which they never saw before, presently the Iournal des Scivans of that Country speaks of it; the people of Iupiter either hear nothing of it, or only laugh at it. The Philosophers, whose Opinions it destroys, are resolved not to believe it; none but the most reasonable doubt of it Observations are repeated, and the little Planet is reviewed; people are certain that 'tis no Vision, and begin to suspect that it moves about the Sun, after a thousand Observations 'tis discover'd that that motion is annual, and at last, thanks to the pains and studies of the Virtuoso's, 'tis known in Iupiter that our Earth is a World, the curious run to gaze on it with their Telescopes, and scarcely is it discernable.

explanations: The French "qui en veulent bien douter" (who are quite willing to doubt it / who indeed want to doubt it) implies a conscious willingness or acceptance of doubt. The English "doubt of it" is a more direct and less nuanced statement, simplifying the psychological aspect by omitting the modal nuance of "veulent bien" (are willing to/indeed want to) which adds a layer of meaning regarding their attitude towards doubting.

The French "même" (even), which emphasizes the surprising or advanced nature of this suspicion, is omitted in the English translation. This removal of the adverb simplifies the sentence by stripping away a layer of emphasis that was present in the original.

The French "on s'asseure bien" (one makes oneself well-assured/certain) implies an active process of verification, with "bien" (well, thoroughly) emphasizing its carefulness. The English "people are certain" states the outcome directly, simplifying by omitting the nuance of the active process of 'making sure' and the thoroughness implied by "bien".

The French "la veüe à peine peut-elle encore l'attraper" personifies "sight" (la veüe) actively struggling to "catch" (attraper) the Earth, with "encore" adding emphasis (still/even). The English "scarcely is it discernable" uses a more passive, abstract construction focusing on the Earth's state ("it is discernable"), simplifying the vivid metaphorical imagery and the active role of "sight." The nuance of "encore" is also diminished.

The French "je croy que cela est" (I believe that that is / is so) contains the explicit assertion "cela est". The English "I believe that," omits the final verb "est" (is) from the object clause, making it less emphatic and more concise. This simplification results in a more common English colloquial expression but loses the full explicit statement of belief present in the French.

The French phrase "à composer des Lunettes excellentes" (to compose/construct excellent telescopes) uses the verb "composer." While accurate for construction, "composer" is somewhat more formal or less frequently used in general parlance than "make." The English translation opts for "to make excellent Telescopes," employing the more common and straightforward verb "make." This represents a simplification in vocabulary choice.

chunks.sourceHtml: P074: Si ce n'estoit, dit la Marquise, qu'il n'est point trop agreable de sçavoir qu'on ne nous peut découvrir de dedans Jupiter qu'avec des Lunettes d'approche, je me representerois avec plaisir ces Lunettes de Jupiter dressées vers nous, comme les nostres le sont vers luy, & cette curiosité mutuelle avec laquelle les Planetes s'entre-considerent & demandent l'une de l'autre, Quel monde est-ce-là? Quelles Gens l'habitent?
chunks.manualHtml: P068: If it were not, said the Marchioness, that it is not very satisfactory to know that from Iupiter they cannot discover us without a Telescope. I should take pleasure in representing to my self those Telescopes of Iupiter planted toward us as ours are to behold him, and that mutual curiosity of the two Planets in considering one another, and asking What World is this? What People inhabit here?

I should take pleasure in representing to my self those Telescopes of Iupiter planted toward us as ours are to behold him, and that mutual curiosity of the two Planets in considering one another, and asking What World is this? What People inhabit here?
explanations: The French phrase "de dedans Jupiter" (literally "from inside of Jupiter" or "from within Jupiter") is simplified to "from Iupiter". This reduces the specificity and slight redundancy of the original, making the English phrasing more concise and direct, thereby reducing textual density.

The French phrase "vers luy" (towards him) indicates only direction. The English translation "to behold him" makes the purpose of this direction explicit (i.e., to observe or see him). This explicitation simplifies the text for the reader by reducing the inferential load and making the meaning more immediately accessible.

The original French uses a relative clause structure ("avec laquelle les Planetes s'entre-considerent & demandent" – with which the Planets consider each other and ask). The English translation changes this to a construction using participial phrases ("of the two Planets in considering... and asking"). This shift simplifies the sentence structure by replacing a more formal subordinate clause with a more fluid participial construction common in English, potentially enhancing readability. Additionally, the French "les Planetes ... l'une de l'autre" (the Planets ... one of the other) is made more explicit in the English pre-modification "the two Planets", slightly reducing ambiguity.

chunks.sourceHtml: P075: Cela ne va pas si viste que vous pensez, repliquay-je. Quand on verroit nostre Terre de dedans Jupiter, quand on l'y connoistroit, nostre Terre ce n'est pas nous; on n'a pas le moindre soupçon qu'elle puisse estre habitée. Si quelqu'un vient à se l'imaginer, Dieu sçait comme tout Jupiter se moque de luy. Peut-estre mesme sommes-nous cause qu'on y a fait le procés à des Philosophes qui ont voulu soûtenir que nous estions. Cependant je croirois plus volontiers que les Habitans de Jupiter sont assez occupez à faire des découvertes sur leur Planete, pour ne songer point du tout à nous. Elle est si grande, que s'ils navigent, asseurément leurs Cristophles Colombs ne sçauroient manquer d'employ. Il faut que les Peuples de ce Monde-là ne connoissent pas seulement de réputation la centiéme partie des autres Peuples, au lieu que dans Mercure, qui est fort petit, ils sont tous voisins les uns des autres, ils vivent familierement ensemble, & ne comptent que pour une promenade de faire le tour de leur Monde. Si on ne nous voit point dans Jupiter, vous jugez bien qu'on y voit encore moins Venus & Mercure, qui sont des Mondes, & plus petits, & plus éloignez de luy. En récompense ses Habitans voyent Mars, & leurs quatre Lunes, & Saturne avec les siennes. Voila assez de Planetes pour embarasser ceux d'entre eux qui sont Astronomes; la Nature a eu la bonté de leur cacher ce qui en reste dans l'Univers.
chunks.manualHtml: P069: Hold, said I, that's not so soon done as you imagine: should the Inhabitants of Iupiter see our Earth, and know it, yet our Earth is not our selves; there would not be the least suspicion that 'tis inhabited: and should any one chance to entertain such a thought, God knows how the whole World of Iupiter would mock him. Nay possibly we have already been the cause of arraigning some of their Philosophers for holding that we have a Being in Nature. In the mean time I rather believe, that the Inhabitants of Iupiter have imployment enough in making discoveries in their own Planet, without ever dreaming of us; it is so big, that if they have the Art of Navigation, their Christopher Columba's have most certainly imployment enough. It must needs be that the people of that World do not know the hundredth part of it; whereas in Mercury, which is very little, they are all Neighbours, live very familiarly together, and count it but a Walk, to make a turn about their World. If they do not see us from Iupiter, you will easily judge that the people of that Planet do much less see Venus and Mercury, which are both lesser Worlds, and more distant from him. But to make amends, his inhabitants see Mars, and their own four Moons, and Saturn with his. These are Planets enough to perplex their Astronomers, and Nature has been so kind to conceal the rest of the Universe from them.

explanations: The translation simplifies the original French phrase "Cela ne va pas si viste" (Literally: That doesn't go so fast) into the more common English idiom "that's not so soon done." The addition of the interjection "Hold" also makes the dialogue more direct and less formal than the French "repliquay-je" coupled with the slightly more abstract original statement.

The French "ne sçauroient manquer d'employ" is an idiomatic construction involving a modal verb and negation (literally "would not know how to lack employment" or "could not fail to have employment"), indicating certainty through a relatively complex syntactic structure. The English "have most certainly imployment enough" expresses this certainty using a more direct affirmative statement with an adverb, simplifying the original's syntactic complexity.

The translation simplifies the original by omitting the qualifying phrase "seulement de réputation" (even by reputation). It also changes the object of the verb "connoissent" (know) from "la centiéme partie des autres Peuples" (the hundredth part of the other Peoples [on their own world]) to "the hundredth part of it" (referring to their world itself). This reduces the informational detail and simplifies the specific social implication of internal unawareness among different groups to a more general unawareness of the planet's vastness.

The French phrase "ceux d'entre eux qui sont Astronomes" (literally, "those among them who are Astronomers") is a descriptive relative clause. The English translation simplifies this to the more concise possessive phrase "their Astronomers," reducing the structural complexity and length of the characterization.

The French phrase "vous jugez bien que..." implies that the listener's judgment is correct or well-founded ("you rightly judge that..."). The English translation "you will easily judge that..." simplifies this by rendering "bien" (well/rightly) as "easily." This shifts the nuance from the correctness of the judgment to the facility with which it can be made, using a more common and less nuanced adverbial construction compared to a more literal rendering of "bien".

chunks.sourceHtml: P076: Quoy, dit la Marquise, vous comptez cela pour une grace? Sans doute, répondis-je. Il y a dans tout ce grand Tourbillon seize Planetes. La Nature qui veut nous épargner la peine d'étudier tous leurs mouvemens, ne nous en montre que sept, n'est-ce pas là une assez grande faveur? Mais nous, qui n'en sentons pas le prix, nous faisons si bien que nous attrapons les neuf autres, qui avoient esté cachees; aussi en sommes-nous punis par les grands travaux que l'Astronomie demande presentement.
chunks.manualHtml: P070: How, said the Marchioness, do you count that a kindness? Without doubt it is, said I, there are in all this great Vortex sixteen Planets. Nature, who would save us the trouble of studying all their motions, has let us see but seven of them, is not that a great kindness? But we, who know not how to value it, have taken a course to find out the other nine that were conceal'd, and are punish'd for our pains by the great labour that Astronomy at present requires.

Nature, who would save us the trouble of studying all their motions, has let us see but seven of them, is not that a great kindness? But we, who know not how to value it, have taken a course to find out the other nine that were conceal'd, and are punish'd for our pains by the great labour that Astronomy at present requires.
explanations: The French phrase "nous faisons si bien que nous attrapons" (literally 'we do so well that we catch' or 'we manage so that we catch') implies a certain adroitness or perhaps the effective, if meddlesome, consequence of human actions leading to discovery. The English translation "have taken a course to find out" simplifies this by employing a more straightforward and neutral expression that denotes a deliberate, methodical process. This change lessens the idiomatic richness and potential ironic undertone of the original French, which subtly comments on human ingenuity or overreach.

The French phrase "une assez grande faveur" includes the word "assez" (which can mean 'enough', 'sufficiently', or 'rather/quite') to qualify the magnitude of the "faveur" (favor/kindness). This adds a nuance about its degree or adequacy. The English translation "a great kindness" simplifies this by omitting an equivalent for "assez." This renders the statement more absolute and less nuanced, as it presents the kindness as simply "great" without the original's specific qualification of degree or sufficiency.

chunks.sourceHtml: P077: Je voy, reprit-elle, par ce nombre de seize Planetes qu'il faut que Saturne ait cinq Lunes. Il les a aussi, repliquay-je, & de ces cinq Lunes, il y en a deux bien fraischement découvertes; mais il ya a quelque chose qui est encore bien plus remarquable. Comme son année est de trente des nostres, & que par consequent il a des Pays, où une seule nuit dure des quinze ans entiers, devinez ce que la Nature a inventé pour éclaires des nuits si affreuses. Elle ne s'est pas contentée de donner cinq Lunes à Saturne, elle a mis autour de luy un grand Cercle, ou un grand Anneau qui l'environne entierement, & qui estant assez élevé pour estre hors de l'ombre du Corps de cette Planete, refléchit perpetuellement la lumiere du Soleil dans les lieux qui ne le voyent point.
chunks.manualHtml: P071: I find, says she, by that number of sixteen Planets, that Saturn ought to have five Moons. He has so, says I, and of those five, two are but lately discovered; but there is a thing yet much more remarkable, one of his years being thirty of ours, and by consequence there being Countreys in him, whose night is of fifteen years continuance, guess you what Nature has invented to inlighten such terrible nights. She was not satisfy'd with bestowing five Moons upon Saturn, but she has also inclos'd him with a great Circle or Ring, which is high enough raised to be out of the Shadow of the Body of that Planet, and continually reflects the Light of the Sun upon those places that do not see him.
chunks.aiHtml: P071: I find, says she, by that number of sixteen Planets, that Saturn ought to have five Moons. He has so, says I, and of those five, two are but lately discovered; but there is a thing yet much more remarkable, one of his years being thirty of ours, and by consequence there being Countreys in him, whose night is of fifteen years continuance, guess you what Nature has invented to inlighten such terrible nights. She was not satisfy'd with bestowing five Moons upon Saturn, but she has also inclos'd him with a great Circle or Ring, which is high enough raised to be out of the Shadow of the Body of that Planet, and continually reflects the Light of the Sun upon those places that do not see him.
explanations: The French presents two main actions of Nature; the second ('elle a mis...') logically follows the first ('Elle ne s'est pas contentée de donner...') implying an additive contrast ('not only... but also...'). The English translation makes this relationship explicit by using 'but she has also', clarifying the connection for the reader. Additionally, the descriptive relative clause 'qui l'environne entierement' (which surrounds it entirely), modifying 'un grand Anneau' in the French, is not directly translated. Instead, its meaning is partially absorbed into the verb 'inclos'd him with', and the specific adverb 'entierement' (entirely) is omitted. This combination streamlines the sentence by making the logical structure more overt while reducing descriptive detail and length.

The French original uses a structure with explicit subordinate clauses introduced by 'Comme...' (As...) and '...que par consequent...' (and that consequently...). The English translation rephrases this using absolute participial constructions ('one of his years being...', 'there being Countreys...'). This change simplifies the sentence structure by removing explicit subordinating conjunctions and casting the information into more compact phrases, streamlining the presentation of the premises.

The French phrase 'bien fraischement découvertes' translates to 'very recently discovered,' where 'bien' acts as an intensifier. The English translation 'but lately discovered' means 'only recently discovered.' While 'lately' conveys 'recently' (fraischement), the intensifier 'bien' (very) is not directly translated with an equivalent intensifier. This results in a slight reduction of emphasis and nuanced expression, simplifying the original's forcefulness.

chunks.sourceHtml: P078: En verité, dit la Marquise, de l'air d'une personne qui rentroit en elle-mesme avec étonnement, tout cela est d'un grand ordre; il paroist bien que la Nature a eu en veüe les besoins de quelques Estres vivans, & que la distribution des Lunes n'a pas esté faite au hazard. Il n'en est tombé en partage qu'aux Planetes éloignées du Soleil, à la Terre, à Jupiter, à Saturne, car ce n'estoit pas la peine d'en donner à Venus & à Mercure, qui ne reçoivent que trop de lumiere, dont les nuits sont fort courtes, & qui les comptent apparemment pour de plus grands bienfaits de la Nature que leurs jours mesmes. Mais attendez, il me semble que Mars, qui est encore plus éloigné du Soleil que la Terre, n'a point de Lune. On ne peut pas vous le dissimuler, répondis-je, il n'en a point, & il faut qu'il ait pour ses nuits des ressources que nous ne sçavons pas. Vous avez veu des Phosphores, de ces matieres liquides ou seches, qui en recevant la lumiere du Soleil, s'en imbibent, & s'en penetrent, & ensuite jettent un assez grand éclat dans l'obscurité. Peut-estre Mars a-t-il de grands Rochers fort élevéz, qui sont des Phosphores naturels, & qui prennent pendant le jour une provision de lumiere qu'ils rendent pendant la nuit. Vous ne sçauriez nier que ce ne fust un Spectacle assez agreable, de voir tous ces Rochers s'alumer de toutes parts dés que le Soleil seroit couché, & faire sans aucun art des illuminations magnifiques. Vous sçavez encore qu'il y a en Amerique des Oyseaux qui sont si lumineux dans les tenebres, qu'on s'en peut servir pour lire. Que sçavons-nous si Mars n'a point un grand nombre de ces Oyseaux, qui dés que la nuit est venuë, se dispersent de tous costéz, & vont répandre un nouveau jour?
chunks.manualHtml:
P072: Seriously and truly, says the Marchioness, with an Air of one astonish'd, all this is a work of great Order, it is very visible that Nature had in her eye the Necessities of every living Being, and that the Distribution of Moons was not a thing done at random. There's none share in it but the Planets farthest distant from the Sun, viz. the Earth, Iupiter and Saturn; for it was not worth the while to give them to Venus and Mercury, who receive but too much Light, whose Nights are short, and which they esteem a much greater benefit of Nature than their Days.

P073: But stay, says she, methinks Mars, who is father remov'd from the Sun than the Earth is, has no Moon. It cannot be deny'd, said I, he has none, and therefore he must have some other refuge in his nights than we know of. You have seen those Phosphores, of either dry or liquid matter, which receiving the Light of the Sun, imbibe it, and diffusing it in the dark, give a considerable light. Perhaps Mars has great Rocks high rais'd, which are natural Phosphores, and which in the day time make a provision of Light, which they disburse in the night. You cannot deny that it would be a delightful spectacle to see all those Rocks lighted at Sunset, and make magnificent Illuminations without any Art. You know likewise that there are in America certain Birds so luminous, that they give light enough to read by in the dark. How do we know but Mars has a great many of those Birds, which at nightfall disperse themselves every where, and create a new day?

explanations: The French phrase "qui rentroit en elle-mesme avec étonnement" conveys a nuanced image of the Marquise withdrawing into herself in astonishment or reflecting with astonishment. The English translation "with an Air of one astonish'd" simplifies this by omitting the reflexive action of "rentroit en elle-mesme" (withdrawing into herself / reflecting), reducing the description to a more direct state of being "astonish'd." This makes the image less complex.

The French "Il n'en est tombé en partage qu'à..." is a somewhat formal and idiomatic passive construction meaning "only ... received them as their share." The English translation "There's none share in it but..." simplifies this to a more direct construction using common vocabulary, making the sentence structure less complex and more immediately understandable.

The translator simplified the phrase by omitting the intensifier "fort" (very) from "fort courtes" (very short). This reduces the descriptive detail slightly, making the statement more concise and arguably simpler by removing a degree of emphasis.

The translation simplifies the original by omitting "apparemment" (apparently), which removes a nuance of speculation and makes the assertion more direct. It also omits "mesmes" (very/even), which was used for emphasis with "leurs jours" (their days). These omissions reduce the complexity and qualification of the original statement.

The French "encore plus éloigné" (even further/still further) includes the nuance of "encore" (still/even), emphasizing a progression or additional degree of distance. The English "father remov'd" (farther removed) is a direct comparative but omits this subtle emphasis provided by "encore", simplifying the comparative idea slightly.

The French "On ne peut pas vous le dissimuler" translates to "One cannot hide it from you" or "It cannot be concealed from you." The English "It cannot be deny'd" simplifies the concept. While both express an admission, "dissimuler" implies a potential prior or active act of hiding or dissembling, a more complex notion than simply being "denied." The translation opts for a more common and straightforward term.

The French "& il faut qu'il ait... des ressources" (and it is necessary that he has... resources) is translated with "and therefore he must have... some other refuge." The addition of "therefore" makes the logical connection (causality from having no moon) more explicit than the simple conjunction "&" (and) in French. This explicitation guides the reader's understanding more directly, simplifying the inferential step.

The French text uses two distinct reflexive verbs, "s'en imbibent" (are imbued with it / soak it up) and "s'en penetrent" (are penetrated by it), to describe how the phosphorescent materials absorb light, emphasizing a thorough saturation. The English translation simplifies this by using only the verb "imbibe it," omitting the concept of penetration ("s'en penetrent"). This reduces the descriptive richness and density of the original phrase.

The French "fort élevéz" means "very high" or "very elevated." The English translation "high rais'd" omits the intensifier "fort" (very). This lessens the emphasis on the height of the rocks, simplifying the description by removing a degree of intensity.

The French "Vous ne sçauriez nier que ce ne fust..." employs the conditional "sçauriez nier" (you could not deny) and the subjunctive "fust" with an expletive "ne," creating a grammatically complex and formal polite construction. The English "You cannot deny that it would be..." simplifies this to a more direct indicative mood ("cannot deny") and a standard conditional ("would be"), reducing the grammatical intricacy of the original.

The French "s'alumer de toutes parts" (lighting up on all sides/from all parts) provides a vivid detail about the pervasiveness of the illumination. The English "lighted" omits "de toutes parts," simplifying the visual by removing this spatial detail. Additionally, "dés que le Soleil seroit couché" (as soon as the Sun would be/were set), which conveys a conditional or habitual aspect about the timing, is condensed to the simpler, more general "at Sunset."

The French word "tenebres" is a somewhat more literary and intense term for "darkness" or "gloom." The English translation uses "in the dark," which is a more common and less stylistically marked term, representing a simplification of vocabulary.

The French "qu'on s'en peut servir pour lire" (that one can make use of them to read) is a more general statement about their utility. The English "that they give light enough to read by" simplifies by making the mechanism of their usefulness explicit ("they give light enough"). This explicitation reduces the inferential step for the reader.

The French phrase "dés que la nuit est venuë" (literally, "as soon as the night has come") is slightly more narrative and descriptive of the moment night begins. The English "at nightfall" is more concise and idiomatic, simplifying the temporal expression into a single, common noun phrase.

The French "se dispersent de tous costéz" (disperse themselves on all sides / in all directions) offers a slightly more specific and dynamic image of dispersal. The English "disperse themselves every where" is more general and arguably less vivid, a subtle simplification by reducing the specificity of the spatial description.

The French "& vont répandre un nouveau jour?" (literally, "and go to spread/diffuse a new day?") uses the verb "répandre" (to spread, diffuse) in a somewhat figurative sense. The English "and create a new day?" simplifies this by using the more direct and less metaphorical verb "create," making the intended meaning more straightforward.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P079: Je ne me contente, reprit-elle, ny de vos Rochers, ni de vos Oyseaux. Cela ne laisseroit pas d'estre joly, mais puis que la Nature a donné tant de Lunes à Saturne & à Jupiter, c'est une marque qu'il faut des Lunes. J'eusse esté bien-aise que tous les Mondes éloignez du Soleil en eussent eu, si Mars ne nous fust point venu faire une exception desagreable. Ah! vrayment, repliquay-je, si vous vous mêliez de Philosophie plus que vous ne faites, il faudroit bien que vous vous accoûtumassiez à voir des exceptions dans les meilleurs Sistêmes. Il y a toûjours quelque chose qui y convient le plus juste du monde, & puis quelque chose aussi qu'on y fait convenir comme on peut, ou qu'on laisse-là, si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout. Usons-en de mesme pour Mars, puis qu'il ne nous est point favorable, & ne parlons point de luy. Nous serions bien étonnez, si nous estions dans Saturne, de voir sur nos testes pendant la nuit ce grand Anneau qui iroit en forme de demy Cercle d'un bout à l'autre de l'Horison, & qui nous renvoyant la lumiere du Soleil feroit l'effet d'une Lune continuë. Et ne mettrons-nous point d'Habitans dans ce grand Anneau, interrompit-elle en riant? Quoy que je sois d'humeur, répondis-je, à en envoyer par tout assez hardiment, je vous avoüe que je n'oserois en mettre là, cet Anneau me paroist une habitation trop irreguliere. Pour les cinq petites Lunes, on ne peut pas se dispenser de les peupler. Si cependant l'Anneau n'estoit, comme quelques-uns le soupçonnent, qu'un Cercle de Lunes qui se suivissent de fort prés, & eussent un mouvement égal, & que les cinq petites Lunes fussent trois échapées de ce grand Cercle, que de Mondes dans le Tourbillon de Saturne! Quoy qu'il en soit, avec le secours même de l'Anneau, les Gens de Saturne sont assez miserables. Il leur donne de la lumiere, mais quelle lumiere, dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil! Le Soleil même n'est pour eux qu'une petite Etoile blanche & pâle, qui n'a qu'un éclat & une chaleur bien foible, & si vous les mettiez dans nos Pays les plus froids, dans la Groënlande, ou dans la Laponie, vous les verriez suër à grosses gouttes & expirer de chaud.

P080: Vous me donnez une idée de Saturne qui me gele, dit la Marquise, au lieu que tantost vous m'échauffiez en me parlant de Mercure. Il faut bien, repliquay-je, que les deux Mondes qui sont aux extremitez de ce grand Tourbillon, soient opposées en toutes choses.
chunks.manualHtml: P074: I am not satisfy'd, says she, neither with your Rocks nor your Birds; not but that it may be very pretty; but since Nature has given so many Moons to Saturn and Iupiter, 'tis a sign there is occasion for them. I should have been glad that all the Worlds far distant from the Sun had them likewise, but Mars I find makes a disagreeable exception. Ah! says I, if you look'd more into Philosophy than you do , you would accustom your self to find exceptions in the best Systems. There is ever something that agrees very well, and something that we make agree as well as we can, or else we let it alone, if we despair of succeeding well in it. Let us deal so with Mars: since he doth not favour us, let us e'en say no more of him. We should be sufficiently astonished if we were in Saturn, to see over our heads in the night that great Ring, which moving in form of a Semicircle from one end of the Horizon to the other, reflects the Light of the Sun, and performs the office of a perpetual Moon. And, says the Marchioness, laughing, must we not likewise have Inhabitants in that great Ring? Truly said I, however I may be bold enough to plant them every where else, I must confess, I dare not place any there, that Ring seems a habitation too irregular. But as for the five little Moons, I think we cannot well dispense with peopling them; if in the mean time that Ring be, as some suspect, no more than a circle of Moons that follow one another very close with an equal motion, and that the five little Moons are such as have made their escape from the great Circle, what an infinity of Worlds shall we have in that Vortex of Saturn? however it be, the people of Saturn, with all the help of that Ring, are miserable enough. It gives them light, but what sort of a light at that distance from the Sun? the Sun it self is to them but a small Star, pale and wan, and has only a little glittering and a feeble heat. Were they brought into the coldest of our Countrys, as Groenland or Lapland, you would see them melt and expire with heat. You give me, says the Marchioness, an Idea of Saturn that freezes me, as just now you heated me in your discourse of Mercury. It must needs be, says I, that two Worlds that are in the extermities of this great Vortex, should be opposite in all things.
